Forming the Longe Range Air Command.
This decision will give access to some Red Airforce units.

The first three Air Armies, designated 'Air Armies of Special Purpose' were created between 1936 and 1938. The 1st was created on March 1st 1936, the 2nd Air Army was created on March 15th 1937 in the Far East. Somewhat later, the 3rd Air Army was created in the North Caucasus Military District. However, air armies were excluded from the organisational reform of the air forces approved on July 25th 1940. On November 5th 1940, the three existing air armies were reformed as the long range bombardment aviation of the Stavka of the Red Army due to poor combat performance during the conflict with Finland.
You can manually attach this Command to the Moscow MD theatre, as this is the closest to the Stavka.

From May - November 1942, seventeen Air Armies were created from the air forces of the Fronts and Combined Arms Armies, and in December 1944 a long-range aviation Air Army was created as the 18th Air Army. The 1st Air Army was the first created, on May 5th 1942, as part of the Western Front. The next to form during 1942 were the 2nd, 3rd, 4th (May 22nd 1942), 5th, 6th 8th Air Armies (June 1942), 9th/10th/11th/12th (August 1942), 7th and 13th Air Army (November 1942), 14th, 15th, 16th, and 17th Air Armies.
Form the 5th Separate Heavy Tank Brigade.
This decision will give access to a Red Army unit.

The first T-35s formed the 5th Separate Heavy Tank Brigade in Moscow, and paraded on May 1st 1936 on the Red Square. They apparently did not participate in the border wars in Mongolia, the invasion of Poland or the Winter War. By June 1940, they were seen as nearly obsolete and costly to operate, and the question was raised of their demobilization, conversion, or assignation to military academies. They were eventually transferred to the 8th Mechanized Corps in the Kiev district (Ukraine), into the 67th and 68th Tank Regiments of the 34th Tank Division. In the summer of 1941, 90% of these tanks were lost due to mechanical breakdowns, lack of maintenance, fuel, and often sabotaged by their crews, abandoning them. These figures can be explained by the tank's sheer size and the fact it was overweight for its engine and transmission (similar to the T-28). A few surviving vehicles were recorded during the battle of Moscow during the winter of 1941-42.
Build Railway Artillery.
This decision will give access to a Red Army unit.

The Obukhovskii 12"/52 Pattern 1907 gun was a 12-inch (305 mm), 52-caliber naval gun. Mounted aboard battleships of the Imperial Russian Navy and later the Soviet Navy during both world wars, it was later modified by the Soviets and employed as coastal artillery and as a railway gun. \n\nThree railway guns were built, using guns from the sunken battleship Imperatritsa Mariya, which had been lost to a magazine explosion in Sevastopol harbor in October 1916. They were used in the Soviet-Finnish war in 1939-1940.
Form the 109th Rifle Division.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army unit.
109th Rifle Division was raised in Tatarsk (Siberian Military District) in April 1939. The division was motorized in 1940 and used to build the 5th Mechanized Corps, stationed in Chiita.
Rifle Divisions raised in September 1939.
This decision will give you access to some Rifle Divisions.

In early September 1939, the Soviet Union raised new Rifle Divisions in accordance with the developing war situation. §RThis decision will give you access to some divisions that were later used to form Mechanized Corps so don't skip them if you want to get these formations§b.

The 103rd Rifle Division was raised in Voroshilovsk and was converted into a motorized division within the 26th Mechanized Corps.
The 131st Rifle Division was raised in Nezhin (Siberian Military District) in September 1939. The division was engaged in Poland, Finland and Bessarabia before being used to form K. Rokossovsky's 9th Mechanized Corps.
The 146th Rifle Division was raised in August 1939 in the Kiev Military District (KVO). It took part in the invasion of Poland and Bessarabia. In March 1941, it was used to make the 9th Tank Division from the 27th Mechanized Corps (1941). 
The 163rd Rifle Division was raised in August 1939 in Tula. It took part in the Winter War as a reinforced rifle division and was almost destroyed during the battle of Suomussalmi. Remnants of the units were removed to Novgorod and used to make a motorized division, assigned to the 1st Mechanized Corps (1940).
The 173rd Rifle Division was raised in Balashov (Volga Military District) in September 1939. The division was motorized in December and participated in the Winter War, before being transferred to Odessa and used to build the 2nd Mechanized Corps.
The 185th Rifle Division was raised in Orel in September 1939. It participated in the invasion of Lithuania before being converted to a motorized division, assigned to the 21st Mechanized Corps.
Incorporate Baltic Armies.
This decision will give access to Red Army corps.

With the annexation of the Baltic States in summer 1940, the Red Army incorporated Baltic troops into 3 Territorial Rifle Corps:

The 22nd Estonian Rifle Territorial Corps was formed on August 17th 1940 in Tallinn.
The 24th Latvian Rifle Territorial Corps was formed in July 1940 in Riga.
The 29th Lithuanian Rifle Territorial Corps, was formed on August 17th 1940 in Vilnius.

Initially, these units kept part of their equipment and officers, but in the autumn, arrests of soldiers and officers started, as part of the replacement of Baltic people by Russians. Units were not trusted and deployed in the close vicinity of other Soviet units, to avoid desertion. These 3 corps suffered heavy losses and were disbanded after the German invasion of the Baltics. Only the 180th Rifle Division of the 22nd Estonian Territorial Corps perfomed well and became later, in May 1942, the 28th Guards Rifle Division.
Presidentas Smetona.
This decision will give access to a Red Fleet unit..

Germany marched into Klaipeda (Memel), Lithuania. The Lithuanian warship Prezidentas Smetona was left without a harbor. The ship soon settled at Latvia's port of Liepaja. In December Ltn. P. Labanauskas was named captain.\n\nIn 1940 Soviet occupiers called for the ship to raise the Soviet flag, but Captain Labanauskas sailed the ship out of Soviet territory. The ship was later handed over to the Soviet Baltic Fleet. On Jan 11th 1945, it hit a mine and sank off the coast of Finland.
Form a garrison in Hanko.
This decision will give access to a Red Army garrison.

Shortly after the conclusion of the Soviet Finish Winter War and the gain of the Hanko Peninsula, the Soviet Union started to build a naval base that could help in the control and protection of the Gulf of Finland.\nThe Soviet garrison set up in Hanko was composed of the 8th Rifle Brigade, 8th Naval Infantry Brigade and 9th Independant Railway Artillery Division using TM-3 naval guns. These massive guns took part in the defense of the naval base during the Continuation War and they were disabled by Soviet seamen when the base was evacuated in December 1941.
Airborne Brigades.
This decision will give access to Red Army historical units.

The Red Army was a pioneer in the use of airborne forces. Large scale exercises were conducted in 1934 and 1935 which impressed foreign military observers. In July 1936, it was decided to increase the number of airborne brigades from 1 to 3.

The 13th Airborne Brigade was set up in the Kiev Military District.

The 47th Airborne Brigade was raised in the Bielorussian Military District.

3 additional airborne regiments were set up in the Far Eastern Military District.
Form more Airborne Brigades.
This decision will give access to Red Army historical units.

In the summer of 1938, Soviet Airborne Forces were reorganized into 6 Airborne Brigades:

The 202nd, 211th and 212th Airborne Brigades were set up in the Far Eastern Military District

The 201st, 204th and 214th Airborne Brigades were formed in the Leningrad MD, Kiev MD and Bielorussian MD respectively.
Reorganize our Airborne Forces.
This decision will upgrade Red Army historical units.

In May 1941, Soviet Airborne Forces were once again reorganized into 5 Airborne Corps, all stationed in the West. Each corps was composed of 3 brigades and reached 10.000 men in strength.\n\nEven lacking equipment like radios and tanks, these Airborne Corps were at full strength when the war broke out. Despite the precarious situation, Soviet Airborne Corps performed pretty well, offering a fierce resistance against German attacks. All 5 corps were converted into Guards Infantry Rifle Divisions in the spring and summer of 1942.
Form 5 more Airborne Corps.
This decision will give access to Red Army historical units.

In September 1941, the Stavka ordered the formation of 5 new airborne corps, numbered from 6 to 10. Units were supposed to be combat ready in early 1942.\nLike the previous ones, these 5 corps were converted into Guards Rifle Divisions in the summer of 1942.
Soviet-Mongolian Mutual Assistance Pact.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical brigade.

The signature of the Soviet-Mongolian Mutual Assistance Pact happened on March 12, 1936 in Ulaanbaatar, to limit Japanese aggressiveness against Mongolia.\n\nRed Army immediatly started to move mechanized forces in Mongolia: the first unit was despatch from the 11th Mechanized Corps of the Transbaikal Military District. Infantry and artillery elements from the 6th Mechanized Brigade and 3rd Tank Battalion of 32nd Mechanized Brigade were assembled into a new combined unit designed as 'Motorized Armored Regiment' (in russian 'Motobroniy Polk').
Form the Special Motor Armored Brigade.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical brigade.

After a border clash with Japanese troops on March 31, 1936, Red Army transfered a new formation made of mechanized elements of the 5th Mechanized Corps from Moscow Military District.\n\nUnder command of Vasily Fedorovich Shipov, this Special Motor Armored Brigade arrived in Undurhan, 330 km from Ulaanbaatar, in April 1936.
Form the 25th Armored Brigade.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical unit.

The 25th Armored Brigade was formed in August 1936 in Chiita (Transbaikal Military District). It was shortly after renamed to the 25th Tank Brigade in May 1938, before being converted into a Chemical Tank Brigade in July 1938.
1st and 2nd Motorized Chemical Brigades.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical units.

The 1st and 2nd Motorized Chemical Brigades were formed in January 1937, in Iaroslavl and Volsk respectively. They were using small flamethrower light tank models (HT-26s, HT-37/OT-37s).\n\nThese 2 units were renamed in April 1938 to the 30th and 31st Chemical Tank Brigades.
Form the 7th Motor Armored Brigade.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical unit.

In July 1937, Red Army sent another formation, the 7th Motor Armored Brigade, to support the Mongolian People's Republic. Its commander was Nikolai V. Feklenko who later became commander of the 57th Special Corps.
Formation of a new 13th Mechanized Brigade.
This decision will give access to Red Army historical units.

In August 1937, the 13th Mechanized Brigade from 5th Mechanized Corps in Moscow was transferred to 11th Mechanized Corps in the Transbaikal Military District and renamed to the 32nd Mechanized Brigade.

The former 32nd Mechanized Brigade was renamed to the Special Mechanized Brigade (Osobodnaya Mekh. Brigada) and sent abroad to assist the Mongolian's People Republic againt Manchukuo and Japan.

A new 13th Mechanized Brigade was also formed in Kaluga and assigned to 5th Mechanized Corps to compensate for this transfer.
Form the 3rd, 18th, 22nd, 25th and 26th Light Tank Brigades.
This decision will give access to Red Army historical units.

According to the 3rd Five Year Plan for the development and reconstruction of the Red Army (1938-1942), all mechanized brigades were reformed as tank brigades by the addition of a new tank battalion.

A light tank brigade (Legkotankovaya Brigada) was composed of more than 200 tanks, mainly T-26s and BT-5s and later BT-7s, in four battalions, assisted by a motorized infantry battalion and some armored cars.

In January 1938:
23rd Mechanized Brigade became 3rd LTB (Far Eastern Military District)
9th Mechanized Brigade became 18th LTB (Leningrad Military District)
16th Mechanized Brigade became 22nd LTB (Belarus Military District)
18th Mechanized Brigade became 25th LTB (Belarus Military District)
22th Mechanized Brigade became 26th LTB (Kiev Military District).

§RNote for player: Light Tank Brigades were later used to form the new Mechanized Corps of 1940 and 1941, so if you want to get them, do not skip these events.§W
Form 5 more Light Tank and Chemical Tank Brigades.
This decision will give access to Red Army historical units.

In April 1938, 3 more Light Tank Brigades were formed from former units:

8th Mechanized Brigade became 29th LTB (Kiev Military District)
4th Mechanized Brigade became 32nd LTB (Belarus Military District)
7th Mechanized Brigade became 43rd LTB (Far Eastern Military District)

In addition, 2 motorized chemical brigades were reformed as Chemical Tank Brigades (CTB):

1st Mot. Chemical Brigade became 30th CTB (Moscow Military District)
2nd Mot. Chemical Brigade became 31st CTB (Volga Military District).
Form 7 more Light Tank and Chemical Tank Brigades.
This decision will give access to Red Army historical units.

In August, no fewer than 6 Light Tank Brigades and 1 Chemical Tank Brigade were formed, mostly from former units:

12th Mechanized Brigade became 24th LTB (Kiev Military District)
11th Mechanized Brigade became 35th LTB (Leningrad Military District)
3rd Mechanized Brigade became 36th LTB (Kiev Military District)
15th Mechanized Brigade became 38th LTB (Kiev Military District)
2nd Mechanized Brigade became 42nd LTB (Far Eastern MD)
25th Armored Brigade became 33rd CTB (Kiev Military District)

48th Light Tank Brigade was a new formation set up in the Far Eastern Military District.
Form the 10th Tank Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.

In May 1938, former mechanized corps were reformed as tank corps. Each new tank corps was composed of 2 Light Tank Brigades and one Motorized Infantry Brigade.\n\nThe 10th Tank Corps was formed from the former 7th Mechanized Corps in the Leningrad Military District, under the command of General Prokofii L. Romanenko. It was composed of the 1st and 13th LTB and 15th Motorized Infantry Brigade, and was disbanded later to form the 1st Mechanized Corps in June 1940.
Form the 25th Tank Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.

25th Tank Corps was formed from the former 45th Mechanized Corps in Zhitomir (Kiev Military District), under the command of General Ivan O. Iarkin. It was composed of the 4th and 5th LTB and 1st Motorized Infantry Brigade. Its elements served to form the 2nd and 4th Mechanized corps in summer 1940.
Form the 15th Tank Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.

15th Tank Corps was formed in Naro-Fominsk (Moscow Military District), from the units of the former 5th Mechanized Corps, under the command of General Mikhail P. Petrov. It was composed of the 2nd and 27th LTB and 20th Motorized Infantry Brigade. Its elements were later used to form the 1940 and 1941 Mechanized Corps.
Form the 20th Tank Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.

20th Tank Corps replaced 11th Mechanized Corps in Chiita (Transbaikal Military District), under the command of General Boris I. Sheremetov. It was composed of the 8th and 15 LTBs associated with the 5th Motorized Infantry Brigade. 20th Tank Corps was disbanded in 1940 and its elements served to form the new mechanized corps.
Form the 57th Special Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.

57th Special Corps (57-y Osobyy Korpus) was set up in September 1937 in Ulaanbaatar and controlled various units sent to Mongolia to protect this Soviet ally from Japan and Manchoukuo's aggressions. Its commander was Nikolai V. Feklenko.

In summer 1938, this special unit included the 11th Light Tank Brigade, 36th 'Transbaikal' Rifle Division and 3 motorized armored brigades.

In 1939, the 57th Special Corps was involved in the Battle of Khalkin Gol.
Form the 20th, 23rd and 49th Light Tank Brigades.
This decision will give access to Red Army historical units.

In March 1939, 3 new Light Tank Brigades were formed:

The 20th Light Tank Brigade was set up in the Belarus Military District. This brigade served to form the 38th Tank Division of 20th Mechanized Corps (1941)

The 23rd Light Tank Brigade was formed in Pskov (Belarus Military District) from the 17th Mechanized Brigade. It fought in Poland under the 5th Cavalry Corps, before being used to form the 12th Tank Division (8th Mechanized Corps 1940)

The 49th Light Tank Brigade was formed from the 5th Separate Tank Regiment, in Zhitomir (Kiev Military District). Its elements served to form the 44th Tank Division of 18th Mechanized Corps (1941).
Form the 34th, 37th, 39th, 52nd and 55th Light Tank Brigades.
This decision will give access to Red Army historical units.

The 34th Light Tank Brigade was formed using tanks of the 14th Mechanized Brigade in Naro-Fominsk, before being transferred to the Leningrad Military District. It fought with 8th Army in Finland during the Winter War and there was completly destroyed.

The 37th Light Tank Brigade was raised from the second formation of 13th Mechanized Brigade. It was later used to form the 17th Tank Division of 5th Mechanized Corps (1940).

The 39th Light Tank Brigade was formed in the Leningrad Military District and fought in Finland as part of 7th Army. The 55th Light Tank Brigade was formed in the Moscow Military District. Both units served to form the 14th and 18th Tank Divisions of 7th Mechanized Corps (1940).

The 52nd Light Tank Brigade was raised in Kharkov, fought in Finland in the 7th Army and served to form the 18th Tank Division of 7th Mechanized Corps (1940).
Reformation of Heavy Tank Brigades.
This decision will upgrade some Red Army historical units.

From spring to September 1939, the Red Army's Heavy Tank Brigades were reorganized and renamed.

The 21st Heavy Tank Brigade was formed in May in Smolensk (Bielorussian Military District), from the 1st Separate Heavy Tank Brigade. Using T-28 medium tanks, this brigade was assigned to 15th Tank Corps and participated in the invasion of Poland. It was later used to form the 4th Tank Division (6th Mechanized Corps 1940).

The 10th Separate Heavy Tank Brigade was formed in September in the Kiev Special Military Ditrict, from the 4th Separate Heavy Tank Brigade. Also using T-28 medium tanks, this brigade was assigned to 17th Rifle Corps, part of the Zhitomir Army Group during the invasion of Poland. Later it was used to form the 4th and 10th Tank Divisions of 4th Mechanized Corps (1940).

The 14th Separate Heavy Tank Brigade was formed in spring, from the 5th Separate Heavy Tank Brigade. Initialy set up in Kharkov, this brigade was assigned to the Zhitomir Army Group, before the invasion of Poland. It took part in the invasion of Bessarabia. Its medium and heavy tanks (T-35s) were later used to form the 12th and 15th Tank Divisions of 8th Mechanized Corps (1940).

The 20th Separate Heavy Tank Brigade was formed in the Leningrad Special Military District, from the 6th Separate Heavy Tank Brigade. This brigade participated in the war against Finland, and its elements were later used to form the 1st Tank Division, part of 1st Mechanized Corps (1940).
Reorganize our mechanized forces.
The Soviet Union is reorganizing its mechanized forces.

In 1940, the People's Commissariat of Defense (NKO) decided on a large expansion of its mechanized forces by the formation of 16 new light tank brigades, using BT series tanks or T-26s.
The motorization of rifle divisions started, with the conversion of the Moscow Proletarian Rifle Division, 36th Transbaikal Division and the 57th Ural Division.
In summer, after the successes of German armor formations in France, the NKO ordered the formation of 9 new mechanised corps composed of 2 tank and 1 motorized divisions.
In late November 1940, it was also decided to raise more mobile units, including 20 motorised brigades and some light tank brigades.

More mechanized corps were planned for 1941.
Form the 6th and 40th Light Tank Brigades.
This decision will give access to Red Army historical units.

The 6th Light Tank Brigade was formed from the 8th Light Tank Brigade in Chiita (Far Eastern Military District). It fought at Khalkhin Gol and was used to form the 29th Mechanized Corps in 1941.\n\nThe 40th Light Tank Brigade was a completely new formation, assembled in the Leningrad Military District. It fought in Finland and later served to form the 21st Tank Division of 10th Mechanized Corps (1941).
Form the 17th and 41st Light Tank Brigades.
This decision will give access to Red Army historical units.
The 17th and 41st Light Tank Brigades were formed in Yerevan and Tbilisi, in the Transcaucasian Military District. Made up of old T-26s, they were later used to form the 28th Mechanized Corps (1941).
Form the 7th, 30th, 44th, 50th and 70th Light Tank Brigades.
This decision will give access to Red Army historical units.

The 7th Light Tank Brigade was formed using the 6th Light Tank Regiment and 28th Tank Regiment who fought in the Winter War. Set up in Rostov, this unit was disbanded for the formation of 28th Mechanized Corps (1941).

The 30th Light Tank Brigade was a new formation in Vinnitsa (Kiev Military District), later used to form the 32nd Tank Division, part of 4th Mechanized Corps (1940).

The 44th Light Tank Brigade was also a new formation located in Bielsk-Podalski (Belarus Military District), involved in the formation of the 25th Tank Division from 13th Mechanized Corps (1941).

The 50th Light Tank Brigade was formed in Chiita (Transbaikal Military District), used to form the 57th Tank Division of 29th Mechanized Corps (1941).

The 70th Light Tank Brigade was set up in Sverdlovsk. It was used to form the 53rd Tank Division (23rd Mechanized Corps) in 1941.
Form the 2nd, 12th, 14th, 16th, 24th, 31st and 39th Tank Brigades.
This decision will give access to Red Army historical units.

In November 1940, 10 more Tank Brigades were raised.

The 2nd and 14th Tank Brigades were raised in the Leningrad Military District, from reserve units. In 1941, they were used to form the 24th Tank Division (10th Mechanized Corps) and 49th Tank Division (24th Mechanized Corps) respectively.

The 12th, 15th and 16th Tank Brigades were raised in the Bielorussian Military District before being used to form the 26th Tank Division (20th Mechanized Corps), 33rd Tank Division (11th Mechanized Corps) and 36th Tank Division (17th Mechanized Corps) respectively in 1941.

The 23rd Tank Brigade was raised for a second time in the Odessa Military District and used to form the 47th Tank Division of 18th Mechanized Corps (1941).

The 24th Light Tank Brigade was also raised for the second time and used to form the 42nd Tank Division of 21st Mechanized Corps (1941).

The 31st Light Tank Brigade, made up of old T-26s, was raised in Kharkov and later used to form the 55th Tank Division (25th Mechanized Corps).

The 39th Light Tank Brigade was raised for a second time in Berdichev (Kiev Military District) and served for the creation of the 40th Tank Division (19th Mechanized Corps) in 1941. 33rd Tank Brigade was a new formation, used to form 39th Tank Division of 16th Mechanized Corps (1941).
Motorize the 1st Moscow Proletarian Rifle Division.
This decision will upgrade a Red Army historical unit.

The division was first formed in Leningrad, then Petrograd, in November 1918. It was then re-formed either in December 1924 or at the beginning of 1927 in the Moscow Military District, gaining the title of the 1st Moscow Proletariat Red Banner Rifle Division. Pavel Batov was a battalion and then regiment commander in the division in the late 1920s. In August 1939 it raised cadres for the 115th and 126th Rifle Divisions. It was re-raised from its single remaining regiment in September 1939 (2nd formation), but in January 1940 formed the 1st Moscow Motor Rifle Division. On June 22nd 1941 it was part of 7th Mechanised Corps, alongside the 14th and 18th Tank Divisions in the Moscow Military District, assigned to 20th Army. It was the first Soviet formation to use T-34 tanks at Borisov on June 30th, 1941. It fought at Orsha, between Minsk and Moscow, and at Yartsevo in September 1941.\n\n§RNote for player: this division will be removed by event in July 1940 to be attached to the newly formed 7th Mechanized Corps.§W
Motorize the 36th 'Transbaikal' Rifle Division.
This decision will upgrade a Red Army historical unit.

The 36th Transbaikal Rifle Division took part in the battle of Khalkin Gol in summer 1939, as part of the 57th Special Corps. It was later properly motorized and stationed near the town of Chiita. It stayed in the Far East all war long and participated in the Soviet invasion of Manchuria in August 1945.
Motorize the 57th 'Ural' Rifle Division.
This decision will upgrade a Red Army historical unit.
Like the 36th Rifle Division, the 57th 'Ural' Rifle Division took part in the battle of Khalkin Gol. It was motorized in March 1940 and also stayed in the Far East all war long.
Form the 17th Army.
This decision will upgrade a Red Army historical Army.

The 17th Army was formed in June 1940 in the Transbaikal Military District from the elements that fought the Khalkhin Gol Battle against Japan. From 1941 to 1945, the army assumed a general defensive posture, including within Mongolia.\nIt fought in the Soviet invasion of Manchuria in August 1945.
Form the 1st Mechanized Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.

Formation of new mechanized corps started in summer 1940.
Placed under the command of General Mikhail L. Cherniavskii, the 1st Mechanised Corps was assembled in June 1940, using the 1st and 13th Light Tank Brigades, 20th Heavy Tank Brigade, 25th Cavalry Division and 163th Rifle Division.
It was stationed in Pskov as part of the Northwestern Front at the outbreak of the war. After having suffered heavy losses, it was disbanded in early August.

§RNote for player: Soviet Mechanized Corps were largely destroyed during the first weeks of Barbarossa. For game purposes, they will be removed in mid-1942 to make the new Tank Corps.§W
Form the 2nd Mechanized Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.

The 2nd Mechanised Corps was placed under the command of General Iuri V. Novoselski and assembled using the 15th and 173rd Rifle Divisons, 4th Light Tank Brigade and various tank battalions from other units.\nAs part of the Soviet Union's defense of Bessarabia, it was involved in the fight for the Uman pocket in July 1941, in which it was largely destroyed.
Form the 3rd Mechanized Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.

The 3rd Mechanized Corps was placed under the command of General Aleksei V. Kurkin and assembled using the 21st Heavy Tank Brigade, 2nd Light Tank Brigade, 7th Cavalry Division and 84th Rifle Division.\nIt started the war in Lithuania and was eventually destroyed in July 1941 near Minsk.
Form the 8th Mechanized Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.

The 8th Mechanised Corps was placed under the command of General Ilia P. Alekseenko and assembled using the 4th Cavalry Corps, 23rd Light Tank Brigade, 14th Heavy Tank Brigade, 7th Rifle Division and 34th Cavalry Division.\nPart of 26th Army, Southwestern Front at the beginning of Operation Barbarossa, it was disbanded in July 1941, with the corps command being used to establish the 38th Army.
Form the 4th Mechanized Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.

The 4th Mechanised Corps was placed under the command of General Andrei A. Vlasov and assembled using the 5th and 24th Light Tank Brigades, 10th Heavy Tank Brigade and 81st Rifle Division.\nPart of 6th Army, Southwestern Front, it was completely destroyed in the Uman pocket in 1941.
Form the 5th Mechanized Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.

The 5th Mechanised Corps was placed under the command of General Ilia P. Alekseenko and assembled using the 109th Rifle Division and 15th and 37th Light Tank Brigades.\nBelonging to 16th Army, originally with the Transbaikal Military District, it was ordered to deploy to the west in late May 1941. The unit was disbanded in August 1941.
Form the 6th Mechanized Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.

The 6th Mechanised Corps was placed under the command of General Mikhail G. Khatskilevich and assembled using the 3rd Cavalry Corps, 21st Heavy Tank Brigade, 29th Rifle Division and 11th Cavalry Division.\nPart of the Western Front at the beginning of the war, it scattered in late June during the German assault and was finally destroyed in the Bialystok pocket in late July.
Form the 7th Mechanized Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.

The 7th Mechanised Corps was placed under the command of General Vassili I. Vinogradov and assembled using the 39th and 55th Light Tank Brigades and the already formed 1st Moscow Red Banner Motorized Division.\nFormed in Moscow, the Corps was moved by rail to the front at the outbreak of hostilities with Germany, and ordered to lead counter-attacks on the Vitebsk-Smolensk road, resulting in heavy losses.
Form the 9th Mechanized Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.

9th Mechanized Corps was formed in Novograd-Volynski in late 1940 and placed under the command of General Konstantin K. Rokossovskiy. To create this corps, the Red Army used the 131st Rifle Division, which was then motorized, whereas its armored divisions were newly formed units, lacking 75% tanks by June 1941.
Form the Motorized Brigades.
This decision will give access to Red Army historical units.

By order of the People's Commissariat of Defence (NKO) of November 4th, 1940, 20 Motorized Machine Gun-Artillery Brigades (in Russian : Motorizovannaya Pulemotno-Artilleriyskaya Brigada) were to be raised in the various Military Districts, alongside new tank formations. Each brigade was made up of 4 machine-gun battalions, a rifle and machine-gun battalion, an artillery regiment, a separate anti-aircraft artillery division, some sapper, road, medical and sanitary battalions along with separate tank fire, mortar and reconnaissance companies. They were intended primarily for covering the borders, especially during the concentration of troops in other locations.\n\n§RNote for player. Most of these motorized brigades were used in March 1941 to form the new Mechanized Corps. So don't skip them if you want to get access to these historical formations§W.
Motorize the 69th Rifle Division.
This decision will upgrade a Red Army historical unit.

The 69th Motor Rifle Division was set up in March 1941 by the motorization of the 69th Rifle Division, stationed in Blagoveshchensk (Soviet-Manchukuo border). In June 1941, it was transferred in the West to face the German invasion.\nInitialy, the division was renamed to the 107th Tank Division but, after losing all its tanks, it was designated as the 107th Motor Rifle Division.
Form the 59th Tank Division.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical unit.

The 59th Independant Tank Division was raised from March to June 1941, from the 43rd Light Tank Brigade, 264th Rifle Regiment, 114th Artillery Regiment and 31st Cavalry Division in Zavitaya Station, in the Amur Oblast (Far East Military District). It was transferred to Moscow in mid-July 1941 and used to form the 108th and 109th Tank Divisions.
Form the 10th Mechanized Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.

In 1941, the People's Commissariat of Defence (NKO) ordered the formation of 21 new mechanized corps to reach a total of 30. Most of 1941's formations were lacking tanks or were built up with older models like the T-26.

The 10th Mechanised Corps was formed in Leningrad in March 1941, based on tank regiments that fought in the Winter War. Its commander was General Ivan G. Lazarev.
10th Mechanized Corps was at 50-60% tank strength in June 1941.
Form the 12th Mechanized Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.

12th Mechanized Corps was one of the new formations started in March 1941. It was raised in Siauliau (Baltic Special Military District) and placed under the command of General Nikolai M. Shestopalov.\n12th Mechanized Corps was at 80-90% tank strength in June 1941.
Form the 11th Mechanized Corps in the Bielorussian Military District.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.
11th Mechanized Corps was set up in Volkovysk and placed under the command of General Dmitrii K. Mostovenko, using the former 25th Light Tank Brigade and the 12th Motorized MG Artillery Brigade.
Form the 13th Mechanized Corps in the Bielorussian Military District.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.
13th Mechanized Corps was set up in Bielsk Podlaski and placed under the command of General Piotr N. Akhlustin, using the former 44th Light Tank Brigade and the 14th Motorized MG Artillery Brigade.
Form the 14th Mechanized Corps in the Bielorussian Military District.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.
14th Mechanized Corps was set up in Kobrin and placed under the command of General Stepan I. Oborin, using the former 29th and 32nd Light Tank Brigades and the 3rd Motorized MG Artillery Brigade.
Form the 17th Mechanized Corps in the Bielorussian Military District.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.
17th Mechanized Corps was set up in Baranovichi and placed under the command of General Mikhail P. Petrov, using the former 16th Light Tank Brigade and the 13th Motorized MG Artillery Brigade.
Form the 20th Mechanized Corps in the Bielorussian Military District.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.
20th Mechanized Corps was set up in Borisov and placed under the command of General Andrei G. Nikitin, using the 4th Cavalry Division alongside the 12th and 20th Light Tank Brigades.
Form 15th Mechanized Corps in the Kiev Special Military District.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.
15th Mechanized Corps was set up in Brody and placed under the command of General Ignatii I. Karpezo, using the 6th Motorized MG Artillery Brigade alongside the 18th and 30th Light Tank Brigades.
Form 16th Mechanized Corps in the Kiev Special Military District.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.
16th Mechanized Corps was set up in Tjernovsty and placed under the command of General Aleksandr D. Sokolov, using the 26th Light Tank Brigade.
Form 19th Mechanized Corps in the Kiev Special Military District.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.

19th Mechanized Corps was set up in Zhitomir and placed under the command of General Nikolai F. Feklenko, using the 22th Motorized MG Artillery Brigade alongside the 35th and 39th Light Tank Brigades.
Form 22th Mechanized Corps in the Kiev Special Military District.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.
22nd Mechanized Corps was set up in Lutsk and placed under the command of General Semion M. Kondrusev, using the 15th Motorized MG Artillery Brigade alongside the 36th and 38th Light Tank Brigades.
Form 24th Mechanized Corps in the Kiev Special Military District.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.

24th Mechanized Corps was set up in Preskurov and placed under the command of General Vladimir I. Chistiakov, using the 18th and 20th Motorized MG Artillery Brigades alongside the 2nd and 14th Light Tank Brigades.
Form the 18th Mechanized Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.
18th Mechanized Corps was set up in Akkerman, in the Odessa Military District. Under the command of General Piotr V. Volokh. It only mustered 27% of its tank strength by June 1941.
Form the 21st Mechanized Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.

21st Mechanized Corps was set up in the Moscow Military District and placed under the command of General Dmitrii D. Lelyushenko. It took part in the defensive operations in the Baltics before being disbanded in late August 1941.
Form the 23rd Mechanized Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.
Set up in the Orel Military District, 23rd Mechanized Corps was placed under the command of General Mikhail A. Miasnikov. In June 1941, it was only at 35 to 40% tank strength.
Form the 25th Mechanized Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.
25th Mechanized Corps was set up in the Kharkov Military District, under the command of General Semion M. Krivoshein.
Form the 26th Mechanized Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.
26th Mechanized Corps was raised in the North Caucasus Military District and placed under the command of General Nikolai I. Kirichenko, using the former 10th and 12th Cavalry Divisions.
Form the 27th Mechanized Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.
27th Mechanized Corps was formed in the Central Asia Military District and placed under the command of General Ivan I. Petrov, using the former 19th Mountain and 146th Rifle Divisions.
Form the 28th Mechanized Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.
28th Mechanized Corps was formed in Yerevan and placed under the command of General Vasilii V. Novikov. It was transformed into 47th Army on August 1st, 1941.
Form the 29th Mechanized Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.

29th Mechanized Corps was the last mechanized formation set up in March 1941, in the Soviet Far East. Unlike previous corps, it was a full strength formation because the Soviet Union was maintaining troops at combat readiness in the region due to Japanese aggressions. 29th Mechanized Corps was placed under the command of General Mikhail I. Pavelkin, using the former 50th and 11th Light Tank Brigades, 15th Cavalry Division, 82nd Rifle Divison and the 16th Motorized MG Artillery Brigade.
Form the 30th Mechanized Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army historical corps.
30th Mechanized Corps was also a full strength formation, made up of the 3rd, 6th, 42nd and 48th Light Tank Brigades and the 23rd Motorized MG Artillery Brigade.
Form 3 Rifle Divisions from the remanining Motorized Brigades.
This decision will give access to Red Army historical units.

In March 1941, unused Motorized Brigades were used to form 3 new Rifle divisions.

The 177th Rifle Division was raised in Leningrad in March 1941 on the basis of the 10th Motorized Machine Gun Artillery Brigade. The division was engaged in various operations from June 1941 to the end of the war and ended up containing the German forces trapped in the Courland Pocket.

The 188th Rifle Division was raised in Leningrad in March 1941 on the basis of the 11th Motorized Machine Gun Artillery Brigade in the Baltics. The division was engaged in various operations beginning in June 1941, from the defence of Lithuania and Latvia, to operations in Bulgaria in 1944.

The 191st Rifle Division was raised in Leningrad in April 1941 on the basis of the 4th Motororized Machine Gun Artillery Brigade. The division was engaged in various operations starting from the defence of Leningrad (summer 1941) to the battle of Berlin in May 1945.
Form the 2nd Shock Army.
This decision will give you access to a full Army.

The Second Shock Army was formed in December 1941 on the Volkov Front. Placed under Lieutenant General Andrei A. Vlasov, it led the Lyuban Offensive in January 1942 to break the Leningrad encirclement. In May 1943, it was virtually annihilated by the German counter-offensive. Vlasov and other prisonners ended forming a Russian anti-communist army (ROA - Russian Liberation Army) who fought alongside German forces.
Form the 72nd Rifle Division.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army Division.

The 72nd Rifle Division was formed for a second time in December 1941 by renaming the 7th Naval Rifle Brigade. It participated in almost all operations on the Leningrad Front from its creation until 1944.
Form the 136th Rifle Division.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army Division.
The 136th Rifle Division was formed in March 1942 on the basis of the 8th Naval Rifle Division. It was renamed to the 63rd Guards Rifle Divison in January 1943.
Form the 308th Rifle Division.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army Division.

The 308th Rifle Division was set up in March 1942 in the Siberian Military District, before being transferred to Saratov and later to the Stalingrad Front. In September 1943 it was renamed to the 120th Guards Rifle Division.
Form the 31st Cavalry Division.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army Division.

31st Cavalry Division was formed a second time in July 1941 in the Voronezh region. It fought within the 49th and 50th Armies near Tula during the Moscow defensive and offensive battles of late 1941. This division was later assigned to the 1st Guards Cavalry Corps and eventually was granted the Guards status on January 5th, 1942, becoming the 7th Guards Cavalry Division.
Form the 11th Cavalry Division.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army Division.
WIP.
Form the 8th Cavalry Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army corps.
8th Cavalry Corps was formed in Tula in January 1942, under the command of General Pavel P. Korzun. It became the 7th Guards Cavalry Corps on February 14th 1943.
Form the 11th Cavalry Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army corps.

The Soviet Union made extensive use of Cavalry Corps during WW2, especially during the first winter of war with Germany. In summer 1942, it became clear that these formations were no match for modern warfare, against tanks and air formations. The Stavka decided to maintain only 8 of these corps, mostly upgraded to Guards status and reinforced by tanks and other armored assets.\n\n11th Cavalry Corps was formed in January 1942 in the Kalinin Oblast and placed under the command of General Grigorii T. Timofeev. It participated in the Rzhev offensive (January-March 1942) and raided in the far rear of the German Army Group Center. It was eventually destroyed during Operation Seydlitz (July 1942) alongside 39th Army.
Reform the 4th Cavalry Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army corps.

The Soviet 4th Cavalry Corps was set up three times. In 1928 it was a territorial formation including cossack units.\nIt was then reformed in 1938 and participated in the Soviet invasion of Poland. In June 1940, the corps headquaters was used to form the new 8th Mechanized Corps.\nFinally, it was reformed a third time in January 1941 in the Central Asia Military District. It took part in the Anglo-Soviet invasion of Iran and was later sent to the Stalingrad Front with the 61st, 63rd and 81st Cavalry Divisions. Eventually, it was disbanded in May 1943 to form the 7th Guards Cavalry Corps.
Form the 7th Naval Rifle Brigade.
This decision will give you access to a Red Navy Brigade.

The 7th Naval Rifle Brigade (Brigada morskoi strelkovy) was raised in September 1941 from elements of the Baltic fleet with many of the men that had previously fought against the Germans in Estonia. The brigade defended positions near Kolpino, on the Leningrad-Moscow railroad and took part in nearly all the operations in that region including the Battle of Krasny Bor (February 10th 1943) against the Spanish Blue Division. It was redesignated to the 72nd Rifle Division in December 1941.
Form the 83rd Naval Infantry Brigade.
This decision will give you access to a Red Navy Brigade.

The 83rd Naval Infantry Brigade (Brigada Morskoy Pekhoty) was raised in August 1942 in Novorossiisk after the fall of Rostov. After defensive actions in summer 1942, it participated in several amphibious operation, including the recapture of Novorossiisk, landings on the Kerch peninsula and operations up the Danube, into Romania and Hungary. Soldiers of the 83rd Naval Infantry Brigade rode the tanks of the 5th Guards Tank Corps toward Prague when war ended.
Form the 92nd Naval Infantry Brigade.
This decision will give you access to a Red Navy Brigade.

The 92nd Naval Infantry Brigade was raised in Stalingrad in September 1942 from the Volga Flotilla. It was made of only 2 Battalions but distinguished itself holding the Grain Elevator. Chuikov said in 1963 the men were exceptional.
Form the 108th and 109th Tank Divisions.
This decision will give access to Red Army historical units.

108th and 109th Tank Divisions were formed in Moscow in mid July 1941, from the transferred 59th Separate Tank Divison. Thrown in heat of the summer battles of 1941, their T-26 and BT tanks suffered heavy losses. Remnants of these 2 divisions were later used to form some tank brigades in 1942.
Form the 107th Motor Rifle Division.
This decision will upgrade a Red Army historical unit.

Formed from the transferred 69th Motor Rifle Division, and after losing all its tanks in August, the 107th Tank Division became a Motor Rifle Division. This unit distinguished itself in battle and earn the title of "Guards", becoming the 2nd Guards Motorized Division in January 1942 and later, the 49th Guards Rifle Division.
Form the 112th Tank Division and 239th Rifle Division.
This decision will give you access to Red Army historical units.

In August 1941, Stavka started to reform some of its Far Eastern units for a transfer to the Western Front.

112th Tank Division was set up using the 112th Tank Regiment of the 239th Motorized Division (30th Mechanized Corps). Corps commander Andrei L. Getman was assigned to this new tank division made of T-26 light tanks. In November 1941, this tank division was transfered to the West and participated in the Tula defensive and offensive operations. It was reformed as a Tank Brigade in early 1942.

Remnants of the 239th Motorized Rifle Division were used to form a Rifle Division on the July 1939 TOE and were also transfered in November 1941 on the Western Front.The new 239th Rifle Division participated in the operations for the defence of Moscow and later to various battles including Rzhev, Leningrad, Novgorod, Baltics and Silesia.
Form the 121st Tank Brigade.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army historical unit.

121st Tank Brigade was raised on August 24th, 1941 at Kubinka Station, in the Moscow Oblast. This unit was made of volunteers workers from Moscow and fought on various fronts before being converted into 27th GTB on February 7th, 1943.
Form the 28th Tank Brigade.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army historical unit.

28th Separate Tank Brigade was raised on September 22nd, 1941 in the Moscow Military District. Assigned to Western Front, this tank brigade fought under 16th Army, Lev Dovator's 3rd Cavalry Group and later 39th Army. It was granted the Guards status on February 7th, 1943, becoming the 28th Guards Tank Brigade.
Form the 33rd Tank Brigade.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army historical unit.
33rd Tank Brigade was raised on September 22nd, 1941 in Kharkov. It fought under various Armies before being assigned to 2nd Mechanized Corps and eventually, being renamed 57th Guards Tank Brigade.
Form the 145th Tank Brigade.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army historical unit.
145th Tank Brigade was formed on September 6th, 1941 and assigned to various armies on the Western Front.\nEventually it was renamed 43rd Guards Tank Brigade in late 1943.
Form the 146th Tank Brigade.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army historical unit.

146th Tank Brigade was raised on October 13th, 1941 in Gorkiy. It fought under 16th Army, on the Western Front, and was one of the first Soviet unit to use British Lend-Lease Tanks. Eventually it was granted the Guards status on February 7th, 1943, becoming the 29th Guards Tank Brigade.
Form the 56th Tank Brigade.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army historical unit.

56th Tank Brigade was raised on December 10th, 1941 in the Transcaucasion Military District. It fought on the North Caucasus Front and Crimea, being shortly assigned to 23rd and 28th Tank Corps.\nIt was renamed 33rd Guards Tank Brigade on February 7th, 1943.
Form the 52nd Tank Brigade.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army historical unit.

52nd Tank Brigade was raised on December 22nd, 1941 from reserve units elements. It was assigned to the Caucasus front and was granted the Guards status on February 7th, 1943 becoming the 34th Guards Tank Brigade.
Form the 36th Tank Brigade.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army historical unit.

36th Tank Brigade was formed from the remnants of the 41st Tank Division on December 5th, 1941, near the Koposovo railway station. It was assigned to the 22nd Tank Corps in April 1942 before being attached to the 2nd Mechanized Corps raised in early September 1942.
Form the 112th Tank Brigade.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army historical unit.

112th Tank Brigade was set up on January 3rd, 1942 from the remnants of 112th Tank Division. 112th Brigade was placed under command of General Andrei Getman and assigned to the 6th Tank Corps. Part of its equipment was transfered to the 6th Guards Tank Brigade and the unit was placed in reserve before being replenished in January 1943 by a Mongolian People's Republic donation. It was then renamed '112th Red Banner Tank Brigade Revolutionary Mongolia'.\nEventually it became the 44th Guards Tank Brigade (11th Guards Tank Corps) in late 1943.
Form the 192nd Tank Brigade.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army historical unit.
192nd Tank Brigade was raised on February 15th, 1942 and assigned to 61st Army on the Western Front.\nEventually it became the 39th Guards Tank Brigade in late 1943.
Form the 90th Tank Brigade.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army historical unit.

The 90th Tank Brigade was raised in Stalingrad, from February to May 1942 and placed under the command of Lieutenant Colonel Mikhail I. Malyshev.\nThis brigade took part in the Battle of Stalingrad and was granted Guards status, being renamed the 41st Guards Tank Brigade.\nIt was later assigned to the 7th Mechanized Corps in September 1943.
Form the 116th Tank Brigade.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army historical unit.

The 116th Tank Brigade was raised in the Volga Military District, from February to May 1942 and placed under the command of Lieutenant Colonel Anatolii I. Novak. It was assigned to the Bryansk Front and later to the Voronezh Front. In September 1943, it was assigned to the newly formed 8th Mechanized Corps.
Form the 217th Tank Brigade.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army historical unit.

The 217th Tank Brigade was raised in the Gorkiy (Moscow Military District) in Summer 1942 and placed under the command of Lieutenant Colonel Pavel I. Sheleiko. Eventually it was used to form the 2nd Guards Mechanized Corps in November 1942.
Form the 246th Tank Brigade.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army historical unit.

The 246th Tank Brigade was raised in the Gorkiy (Moscow Military District) in Summer 1942 and placed under the command of Lieutenant Colonel Nikolai I. Popov. Eventually it was used to form the 2nd Guards Mechanized Corps in November 1942.
Form the 61st Tank Brigade.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army historical unit.

61st Separate light Tank brigade was raised on July 15th, 1942, and transfered to Leningrad via the Ice road on lake Ladoga.The brigade's composition was slightly modified due to the specifics of the Leningrad Front. The brigade's tank battalions were equipped with T-60 tanks, but a separate armored car battalion with BA-10s was added.\nThe 61st Tank Brigade fought the war attached to 55th and 67th Armies before being renamed as 30th Guards Tank Brigade on February 7th, 1943.
Form the 235th Tank Brigade.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army historical unit.

235th Flamethrower Tank Brigade was formed on September 3rd, 1942 in Lyublino-Kuzminki, near Moscow. This Tank Brigade was equipped with 30 KV and KV-8S Tanks and was deployed on the Stalingrad Front. It was granted the Guards status on February 7th, 1943, becoming the 31st Guards Flamethrower Tank Brigade.
Form the 1st Tank Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army tank corps.

After the destruction of almost all of its mechanized corps in the summer of 1941, Stavka started to build new large armored formations in spring 1942. Soviet "new" tank corps were made of 3 tank brigades assisted by one motorized brigade. In 1942, these corps lacked support units like mobile artillery, engineers or proper AT assets. They were progressively upgraded in 1943 and 1944 to match German armor.

1st Tank Corps was raised in April 1942 and placed under the command of General Mikhail E. Katukov. Its 4 brigades were the 89th, 117th and 159th Tank Brigades and the 44th Motorized Brigade. 1st Tank Corps will get upgrades in February 1943 and March 1944.

§RNote for player: Each new Tank Corps is formed by removing older Mechanized Corps (1940-1941), so they are given for free. Keep in mind that eventually some of these new tank formations get Guards status so don't skip them if you want to get all historical Guards tank units.§W
Form the 2nd Tank Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army tank corps.

2nd Tank Corps was set up in Gorkiy in April 1942 and placed under the command of General Aleksei F. Popov. It consisted of the 26th, 27th and 148th Tank Brigades, assisted by the 2nd Motorized Brigade.\n\nEventually it was renamed to 8th Guards Tank Corps in September 1943.
Form the 3rd Tank Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army tank corps.

3rd Tank Corps was set up in Tula in April 1942 and placed under the command of General Dmitrii K. Mostovenko. It consisted of the 50th, 51st and 103rd Tank Brigades, assisted by the 3rd Motorized Brigade.\n\nEventually it was renamed to 9th Guards Tank Corps in May 1943.
Form the 4th Tank Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army tank corps.

4th Tank Corps was set up in Bryansk in April 1942 and placed under the command of General Vasilii A. Mishulin. It consisted of the 45th, 47th and 102nd Tank Brigades, assisted by the 4th Motorized Brigade.\n\nEventually it was renamed to 5th Guards Tank Corps in February 1943.
Form the 5th Tank Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army tank corps.

5th Tank Corps was set up in Moscow in April 1942 and placed under the command of General Kuzma A. Semenchenko. It consisted of the 24th, 41th and 110th Tank Brigades, assisted by the 5th Motorized Brigade.\n\n§RNote for player: this tank corps will be upgraded in June 1943 and March 1944.§W
Form the 6th Tank Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army tank corps.

6th Tank Corps was set up in Maloyaroslavets in April 1942 and placed under the command of General Andrei L. Getman. It consisted of the 22nd, 112th and 200th Tank Brigades, assisted by the 6th Motorized Brigade.\n\nEventually it was renamed to 11th Guards Tank Corps in September 1943.
Form the 7th Tank Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army tank corps.

7th Tank Corps was set up in Kalinin in April 1942 and placed under the command of General Pavel A. Rotmistrov. It consisted of the 3rd Guards, 62nd and 87th Tank Brigades, assisted by the 7th Motorized Brigade.\n\nEventually it was renamed to 3rd Guards Tank Corps at the end of 1942.
Form the 8th Tank Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army tank corps.

8th Tank Corps was set up in Moscow in May 1942 and placed under the command of General Mikhail D. Solomatin. It consisted of the 25th, 31st and 93rd Tank Brigades, assisted by the 8th Motorized Brigade.\n\nEventually it was renamed to 3rd Mechanized Corps in September 1942.
Form the 9th Tank Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army tank corps.

9th Tank Corps was set up in Moscow in May 1942 and placed under the command of General Aleksei V. Kurkin. It consisted of the 23rd, 95th and 108th Tank Brigades, assisted by the 9th Motorized Brigade.\n\n§RNote for player: this tank corps will be upgraded in June 1943 and March 1944.§W
Form the 10th Tank Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army tank corps.

10th Tank Corps was set up in Gorkiy in May 1942 and placed under the command of General Vasilii G. Burkov. It consisted of the 178th, 183th and 186th Tank Brigades, assisted by the 11th Motorized Brigade.\n\n§RNote for player: this tank corps will be upgraded in June 1943 and March 1944.§W
Form the 11th Tank Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army tank corps.

11th Tank Corps was set up in Gorkiy in late May 1942 and placed under the command of General Aleksei F. Popov. It consisted of the 53rd, 59th and 160th Tank Brigades, assisted by the 12th Motorized Brigade.\n\n§RNote for player: this tank corps will be upgraded in June 1943 and January 1944.§W
Form the 12th Tank Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army tank corps.

12th Tank Corps was set up in Moscow in late May 1942 and placed under the command of General Semion I. Bogdanov. It consisted of the 30th, 97th and 106th Tank Brigades, assisted by the 13th Motorized Brigade.\n\nEventually it was renamed to 6th Guards Tank Corps in June 1943.
Form the 13th Tank Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army tank corps.

13th Tank Corps was set up in Stalingrad in early June 1942 and placed under the command of General Trofim I. Tanaschishin. It consisted of the 65th, 85th and 88th Tank Brigades, assisted by the 20th Motorized Brigade.\n\nEventually it was renamed to 4th Guards Mechanized Corps in January 1943.
Form the 14th Tank Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army tank corps.

14th Tank Corps was set up in Stalingrad in early June 1942 and placed under the command of General Nikolai N. Radkevich. It consisted of the 136th, 138th and 139th Tank Brigades, assisted by the 21st Motorized Brigade.\n\nEventually it was renamed to 6th Mechanized Corps in September 1942, before being renamed again to 5th Guards Mechanized Corps in January 1943.
Form the 15th Tank Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army tank corps.

15th Tank Corps was set up in Moscow in early June 1942 and placed under the command of General Vasilii A. Koptsov. It consisted of the 93rd, 113th and 105th Tank Brigades, assisted by the 17th Motorized Brigade.\n\nEventually it was renamed to 5th Guards Tank Corps in July 1943.
Form the 16th Tank Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army tank corps.

16th Tank Corps was set up in Voronezh in early June 1942 and placed under the command of General Mikhail I. Pavelkin. It consisted of the 107th, 109th and 164th Tank Brigades, assisted by the 15th Motorized Brigade.\n\nIt was upgraded in June 1943 and later renamed to 12th Guards Tank Corps in November 1944.
Form the 17th Tank Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army tank corps.

17th Tank Corps was set up in Stalingrad in early June 1942 and placed under the command of General Nikolai V. Feklenko. It consisted of the 66th, 67th and 174th Tank Brigades, assisted by the 31st Motorized Brigade.\n\nEventually it was renamed to 4th Guards Tank Corps in January 1943.
Form the 18th Tank Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army tank corps.

18th Tank Corps was set up in Stalingrad in late June 1942 and placed under the command of General Boris S. Bakharov. It consisted of the 110th, 180th and 181st Tank Brigades, assisted by the 18th Motorized Brigade. This corps was rapidly transferred to the Bryansk Front.\n\nIt was upgraded in June 1943 and January 1944.
Form the 19th Tank Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army tank corps.

19th Tank Corps was set up in Tula in December 1942 and placed under the command of General Ivan D. Vasilev. It consisted of the 79th, 101st and 202nd Tank Brigades, assisted by the 19th Motorized Brigade.\n\nIt was upgraded in September 1943 and January 1944.
Form the 20th Tank Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army tank corps.

20th Tank Corps was set up in Tula in late December 1942 and placed under the command of General Dmitrii M. Gritsenko. This formation was not fully completed and unusually consisted of the 11th Guards and 155th Tank Brigades, assisted by the 116th Naval Rifle Brigade.\n\nIt was upgraded in July 1943 and January 1944 to proper Tank Corps standards.
Form the 21st Tank Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army unit.

21st Tank Corps was set up in the Southwestern Front in April 1942. Rapidly engaged in the Soviet spring offensive, it was almost annihilated in May 1942 near Kharkov. Only the 64th Tank Brigade survived until the end of 1942.\n\nThis event will remove the old 21st Mechanized Corps and IC costs will be allocated to other new Soviet formations.
Form the 22nd Tank Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army tank corps.

22nd Tank Corps was set up in Kupyansk in April 1942 and placed under the command of General Aleksandr A. Shamshin. Initially it consisted of the 13th, 36th and 168th Tank Brigades, assisted by the 34th Motorized Brigade, but its composition rapidly changed.\n\nIt was converted into the 5th Mechanized Corps a few monthes later, in September.
Form the 23rd Tank Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army tank corps.

23rd Tank Corps was set up in Krasny Oskol in May 1942 and placed under the command of General Abram M. Khasin. It consisted of the 57th, 114th and 131st Tank Brigades, assisted by the 23rd Motorized Brigade.\n\nMade up primarily of US Lend Lease tanks, it was upgraded in June 1943 and January 1944 with artillery and anti-tank assets.
Form the 24th Tank Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army tank corps.

24th Tank Corps was set up in Stalingrad in June 1942 and placed under the command of General Vasilii M. Badanov. It consisted of the 54th and 130th Tank Brigades, 24th Motorized Brigade and 4th Guards Tank Brigade.\n\nIt was granted the Guard status in January 1943, becoming the 2nd Guards Tank Corps.
Form the 25th Tank Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army tank corps.

25th Tank Corps was set up in Moscow in June 1942 and placed under the command of General Piotr P. Pavlov. It consisted of the 111th, 162nd and 175th Tank Brigades, assisted by the 16th Motorized Brigade.\n\nIt was upgraded in July 1943 and January 1944.
Upgrade the 1st Tank Corps (1943).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army tank corps.

The 1st Tank Corps was upgraded in February 1943 with various artillery support elements like SU-76s, mortar regiment and AT guns. Its brigade composition didn't change but Mikhail E. Katukov was replaced by General Vasilii B. Butkov until the end of the war.\n\n§RThe last upgrade will happen in March 1944.§W
Upgrade the 3rd Tank Corps (1943).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army tank corps.

The 3rd Tank Corps was upgraded in May 1943 with various artillery support elements like SU-76s, a mortar regiment and AT guns. It was placed under the command of General Maksim D. Sinenko and was deployed in Bryansk (Central Front).\n\n3rd Tank Corps was renamed to 9th Guards Tank Corps in November 1943.
Upgrade the 5th Tank Corps (1943).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army tank corps.

The 5th Tank Corps was upgraded in June 1943 with various artillery support elements like SU-76s, a mortar regiment and AT guns. It was placed under the command of General Mikhail G. Sakhno and was deployed in Moscow.\n\nEventually this corps was upgraded in March 1944.
Upgrade the 9th Tank Corps (1943).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army tank corps.

The 9th Tank Corps was upgraded in June 1943 with various artillery support elements like SU-76s, a mortar regiment and AT guns. It was placed under the command of General Semion I. Bogdanov and was deployed in Voronezh.\n\nEventually this corps was upgraded in March 1944.
Upgrade the 10th Tank Corps (1943).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army tank corps.

The 10th Tank Corps was upgraded in June 1943 with various artillery support elements like SU-76s, a mortar regiment and AT guns. It was placed under the command of General Vasilii G. Burkov and was deployed in Stary Oskol.\n\nEventually this corps was upgraded in March 1944.
Upgrade the 11th Tank Corps (1943).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army tank corps.

The 11th Tank Corps was upgraded in June 1943 with various artillery support elements like SU-76, a mortar regiment and ZiS-2 AT guns. It was placed under the command of General Nikolai N. Radkevich and was deployed in Bryansk.\n\nEventually this corps was upgraded in January 1944.
Upgrade the 16th Tank Corps (1943).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army tank corps.

The 16th Tank Corps was upgraded in June 1943 with various artillery support elements like SU-76s, a mortar regiment and ZiS-2 AT guns. It was placed under the command of General Vasilii E. Grigorev and was deployed in Voronezh.\n\nEventually 16th Tank Corps became 12th Guards Tank Corps in November 1944.
Upgrade the 18th Tank Corps (1943).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army tank corps.

The 18th Tank Corps was upgraded in June 1943 with various artillery support elements like SU-76s, a mortar regiment and ZiS-2 AT guns. It remained under the command of General Boris S. Bakharov and was deployed in Voronezh.\n\n§RThe last upgrade of this tank corps will happen in January 1944.§W
Upgrade the 19th Tank Corps (1943).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army tank corps.

The 19th Tank Corps was upgraded in September 1943 with various artillery support elements like SU-76s, a mortar regiment and ZiS-2 AT guns. It remained under the command of General Ivan D. Vasilev and was deployed in Stalingrad.\n\n§RThe last upgrade of this tank corps will happen in January 1944.§W
Upgrade the 20th Tank Corps (1943).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army tank corps.

The 20th Tank Corps was upgraded in July 1943 with various artillery support elements like SU-76s, a mortar regiment and ZiS-2 AT guns. It was placed under the command of General Ivan G. Lazarev and was deployed in Tula.\n\n§RThe last upgrade of this tank corps will happen in January 1944.§W
Upgrade the 23rd Tank Corps (1943).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army tank corps.

The 23rd Tank Corps was upgraded in July 1943 with various artillery support elements like SU-76s, a mortar regiment and ZiS-2 AT guns. It was placed under the command of General Efim G. Pushkin and was deployed in Kharkov.\n\n§RThe last upgrade of this tank corps happened in January 1944.§W
Upgrade the 25th Tank Corps (1943).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army tank corps.

The 25th Tank Corps was upgraded in July 1943 with various artillery support elements like SU-76s, a mortar regiment and ZiS-2 AT guns. It was placed under the command of General Fiodor G. Anikushkin and was deployed in Tula.\n\n§RThe last upgrade of this tank corps happened in January 1944.§W
Form the 29th Tank Corps (1943).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army tank corps.

The 29th Tank Corps was raised in March 1943, in Naro Fominsk (Moscow Military District). Under the command of General Evgenii I.Fominykh, it consisted of the 25th, 31st and 32nd Tank Brigades, assisted by the 53rd Motorized Rifle Brigade. It was sent to the Steppe Front in spring, and assigned to the 5th Guards Tank Army.\n\n29th Tank Corps was upgraded in January 1945 and reassigned to the Belorussian Front.
Form the 30th Tank Corps (1943).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army tank corps.

The 30th Tank Corps was raised in April 1943 in the Ural Military District. Under the command of General Georgii S. Rodin, it consisted of the 197th, 243rd and 244th Tank Brigades assisted by the 30th Motorized Rifle Brigade.\n\n30th 'Ural' Tank Corps received Guards status in October 1943, becoming the 10th Guards Tank Corps.
Form the 31st Tank Corps (1943).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army tank corps.

The 31st Tank Corps was created in Oboyan, in March-April 1943, with tank regiments coming from the 1st Tank Army. Placed under the command of General Dmitrii K. Chernienko, it was only made of 3 tank brigades (the 100th, 237th and 242nd) with no motorized infantry brigade in support.\n\nThis corps was upgraded in January 1944 in Moscow before being assigned to the 1st Ukrainian Front, this time supported by the 65th Motorized Rifle Brigade.
Upgrade the 1st Tank Corps (1944).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army tank corps.
The 1st Tank Corps was upgraded in March 1944. It became a more powerful formation, using SU-85s, ISU-122/152 self propelled guns and halftracks from Lend-Lease.
Upgrade the 5th Tank Corps (1944).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army tank corps.
The 5th Tank Corps was upgraded in March 1944. It became a more powerful formation, using SU-85s, ISU-122/152 self propelled guns and halftracks from Lend-Lease.
Upgrade the 9th Tank Corps (1944).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army tank corps.
The 9th Tank Corps was upgraded in March 1944. It became a more powerful formation, using SU-85s, ISU-122/152 self propelled guns and halftracks from Lend-Lease.
Upgrade the 10th Tank Corps (1944).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army tank corps.
The 10th Tank Corps was upgraded in March 1944. It became a more powerful formation, using SU-85s, ISU-122/152 self propelled guns and halftracks from Lend-Lease.
Upgrade the 11th Tank Corps (1944).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army tank corps.
The 11th Tank Corps was upgraded in January 1944. It became a more powerful formation, by the addition of a Heavy Tank Regiment, Zis-3 AT guns and a full complement of US halftracks from Lend-Lease.
Upgrade the 18th Tank Corps (1944).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army tank corps.
The 18th Tank Corps was upgraded in January 1944. It became a more powerful formation, by the addition of a Heavy Tank Regiment, Zis-3 AT guns and a full complement of US halftracks from Lend-Lease.
Upgrade the 19th Tank Corps (1944).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army tank corps.

The 19th Tank Corps was upgraded in January 1944. It became a more powerful formation, by the addition of a Heavy Tank Regiment, Zis-3 AT guns and a full complement of US halftracks and tanks from Lend-Lease.
Upgrade the 20th Tank Corps (1944).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army tank corps.
The 20th Tank Corps was upgraded in January 1944. It became a more powerful formation, by the addition of a Heavy Tank Regiment, Zis-3 AT guns and a full complement of US halftracks from Lend-Lease.
Upgrade the 23rd Tank Corps (1944).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army tank corps.
The 23rd Tank Corps was upgraded in January 1944. It became a more powerful formation, by the addition of a Heavy Tank Regiment, Zis-3 AT guns and a full complement of US halftracks from Lend-Lease.
Upgrade the 25th Tank Corps (1944).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army tank corps.
The 25th Tank Corps was upgraded in January 1944. It became a more powerful formation, by the addition of a Heavy Tank Regiment, Zis-3 AT guns and a full complement of US halftracks from Lend-Lease.
Upgrade the 29th Tank Corps (1945).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army tank corps.

The 29th Tank Corps was upgraded in January 1945. Placed under the command of General Ksenofont M. Malahkov, it became a more powerful formation by the addition of a Heavy Tank Regiment, Zis-3/M30 AT guns, various support tanks (SU-85s and US M-10s) and a full complement of US halftracks from Lend-Lease.
Upgrade the 31st Tank Corps (1945).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army tank corps.

The 29th Tank Corps was upgraded in January 1945. Placed under the command of General Vasilii E. Grigorev, it became a more powerful formation by the addition of a Heavy Tank Regiment, Zis-3/M30 AT guns, various support tanks (SU-85s, SU-76s and SU-122s) and a full complement of US halftracks from Lend-Lease.
Form the 1st Mechanized Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army mechanized corps.

In September 1942, realizing the need for a large mobile unit that could move rapidly, seize objectives deep in the enemys rear area and defend itself against counterattacks, Stavka started the formation of new mobile formations named Mechanized Corps, to support the newly created Tank Corps. Essentially they were large armored divisions with plenty of infantry, composed of 2 tank and 3 motorized infantry brigades.\n\nThe 1st Mechanized Corps was assigned to the Kalinin Front and placed under the command of General Mikhail D. Solomatin. It got upgraded in 1943 and 1944.
Upgrade the 1st Mechanized Corps (1943).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army mechanized corps.
1st Mechanized Corps was upgraded in June 1943 with the addition of AT assets and assigned to the Steppe Front. The 65th Tank Brigade was removed and assigned to the 11th Tank Corps.
Upgrade the 1st Mechanized Corps (1943).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army mechanized corps.
1st Mechanized Corps was upgraded in August 1944 by the addition of mobile artillery assets like SU-76s, SU-85s and ISU-152s. It was assigned to the 1st Belorussian Front.
Form the 2nd Mechanized Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army mechanized corps.

2nd Mechanized Corps was formed in September 1942 and assigned to the Kalinin Front. It was placed under the command of General Ivan P. Korchagin and was composed of the 18th, 34th and 43rd Mechanized Brigades assisted by 33rd and 36th Tank Brigades.\nIn September 1943, it was granted the Guards status and renamed the 7th Guards Mechanized Corps, while the 36th Tank Brigade was transferred to 11th Tank Corps.
Form the 3rd Mechanized Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army mechanized corps.

3rd Mechanized Corps was formed in November 1942 from the former 8th Tank Corps. Assigned to the Kalinin Front, it was placed under the command of General Mikhail E. Katukov and was composed of 1st, 3rd and 10th Mechanized Brigades assisted by 1st Guards Tank Brigade and 49th Tank Brigade.\n\nIn October 1943, it was granted the Guards status and renamed the 8th Guards Mechanized Corps.
Form the 4th Mechanized Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army mechanized corps.

In July 1942, Stakva ordered the formation of the 28th Tank Corps that was converted into the 4th Mechanized Corps at the end of the summer. Placed under the command of General Georgii S. Rodin, 4th Mechanized Corps was made up of the 36th, 59th and 60th Mechanized Brigades assisted by 2 tank regiments. \nIn January 1943, it was granted the Guards status and renamed 3rd Guards Mechanized Corps.
Form the 5th Mechanized Corps (1942).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army mechanized corps.

The 5th Mechanized Corps was set up in Moscow in September 1942 from the 22th Tank Corps. Placed under the command of General Mikhail V. Volkov, it was only composed of mechanized brigades (the 45th, 49th and 50th) until April 1943 when it received command of the 188th Separate Tank Brigade.\nThis corps only used UK Lend Lease tanks like Matildas and Valentines.
Upgrade the 5th Mechanized Corps (1943).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army mechanized corps.

The 5th Mechanized Corps was upgraded in August 1943. Still under the command of General M.V. Volkov, its composition changed after the transfer of some brigades. It was now in charge of the 2nd, 9th and 45th Mechanized Brigades assisted by 233rd Tank Brigade.\nUltimately, it was granted the Guards status in August 1944, becoming the 9th Guards Mechanized Corps.
Form the 7th Mechanized Corps (1943).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army mechanized corps.

The 7th Mechanized Corps was ordered in January 1943 but was only completed in September in Moscow. Placed under the command of General Fiodor G. Katkov, it was composed of some experienced units like the 90th Tank Brigade and the 16th Motorized Brigade coming from the 25th Tank Corps, who became the 41st Guards Tank Brigade and the 16th Mechanized Brigade respectively. The 63rd and 64th Mechanized Brigades were, on the other hand, newly formed inexperienced units. 7th Mechanized Corps could rely on a large amount of SU-76 self-propelled artillery elements spread amongst each brigade.\nThe corps became part of the 2nd and 3rd Ukrainian Front, before being transferred to the Soviet Far East against Japan as part of 6th Tank Army.
Form the 8th Mechanized Corps (1943).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army mechanized corps.

The 8th Mechanized Corps was formed in September 1943 in the Moscow Military District and placed under the command of General Aleksandr N. Firsovich. It had 2 experienced formations: the 116th Tank Brigade and 66th Mechanized Brigade, made from the former 50th Mechanized Brigade belonging to the 5th Mechanized Corps. The 67th and 68th Mechanized Brigades were new formations built around 2 experienced Tank Regiments.\nThe 8th Mechanized Corps fought with the 2nd Ukrainian Front and later, in 1945, with the 2nd Belorussian Front.
Form the 9th Mechanized Corps (1943).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army mechanized corps.

The 9th Mechanized Corps was set up in Tula (Moscow Military District) in August 1943. It was composed of only 3 Mechanized Brigades (the 69th, 70th and 71st) under the command of General Konstantin A. Malygin and served within the 3rd Guards Tank Army until the end of war.\nEventually, it was ugraded in October 1944.
Upgrade the 9th Mechanized Corps (1943).
This decision will upgrade a Red Army mechanized corps.

The 9th Mechanized Corps was upgraded with full anti-tank and artillery support units and the addition of the 91st Tank Brigade in October 1944. It participated in the final offensive against Berlin in 1945.
Form the 10th Mechanized Corps (1944).
This decision will give you access to a Red Army mechanized corps.

The 10th Mechanized Corps was set up in the Far Eastern Front in December 1944. Placed under the command of General Aleksandr D. Vasilev, it was reduced in strength to one single tank brigade (the 204th) and 2 mechanized ones (the 42nd and 72nd). This was due to the lack of available tanks in the Far East so the 10th Mechanized Corps was only combat ready in June 1945.\nEventually it participated in the summer offensive against Japan.
Tank Extermination Artillery Divisions.
This decision will give you access to Red Army artillery units.

According to the Resolution No 1607 (April 16th, 1942) of the Stavka, the Red Army started the formation of mobile anti-tank combined arms units called "Tank Extermination Artillery Divisions" or "Tank Destroyer Divisions" (IPTAD).
