Those were made up of a combination of different artillery regiments and battalions of 76mm, 45mm and 37mm AA guns, assisted by engineers, mortars, machine-guns and tanks, and designed as mobile reserves against German armor breakthroughs. Armor battalions were ultimatly assigned to new tank corps and the IPTADs were to rely on their artillery assets.
1st IPTAD was deployed with South-Western Front, 2nd IPTAD with Bryansk Front, 3rd IPTAD with Western Front, 4th IPTAD with Kalinin Front and 5th IPTAD in the Stalingrad Military District.

§RNote for player: For game purposes, these divisions will be removed in winter 1942-1943 to help with the formation of the new artillery divisions.§W.
1st Artillery Division.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army artillery unit.

The 1st Artillery Division was set up in October 1942 on the Eastern bank of the Volga, at Stalingrad. It was the first part of a vast artillery build up decided by the Stavka to turn the tide of the battle. Almost 30 divisions were set up from October 1942 to March 1943 and most of them were upgraded into more powerful units from mid 1943 to the end of war.\n\nThe 1st Artillery Division distinguished itself during the battle of Stalingrad and was granted the Guards status in May 1943.
19th Heavy Artillery Division.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army artillery unit.

The 19th Heavy Artillery Division was also set up in November 1942 in Stalingrad to support the troops defending the city. For its outstanding service, it was granted the Guards status in June 1943, becoming the 5th Guards Breakthrough Artillery Division.
Form artillery divisions.
This decision will give you access to Red Army artillery units.

In December 1942, Stavka assembled a dozen new artillery divisions, made of 4 artillery brigades.

The 2nd Artillery Division was deployed on the Volkov Front.
The 3rd and 6th Artillery Divisions were deployed on the Western Front.
The 4th Artillery Division was deployed on the Don Front.
The 5th Artillery Division was deployed on the Bryansk Front.
The 7th Artillery Division was deployed on the South Western Front.
The 8th Artillery Division was deployed on the Voronezh Front.
The 12th Artillery Division was set up in the Urals.
Other divisions were set up in the Moscow Military District and assigned to the High Command Reserve.

§RKeep in mind that these units are to be upgraded in 1943 into larger and more powerful units, and some will be promoted to Guards status.§W
Form the 26th and 27th Artillery Divisions.
This decision will give you access to Red Army artillery units.

The 26th and 27th Artillery Divisions were set up in December 1942 in the North Western Front.\nThe 27th Artillery Division remained in the Northern part of the front, ending with the siege of the Courland Peninsula whereas 26th Artillery Division was removed and transferred to the Ukrainian and later the Belorussian Front.
Form more Artillery Divisions.
This decision will give you access to Red Army artillery units.

The 14th, 15th, 20th, 21st, 22nd, 23rd, 24th and 27th Artillery Divisions were assembled in the Moscow Military District in January 1943 before being sent to various fronts.
The 16th Artillery Division was raised in the Urals.
All these units were later converted into larger and more powerful units.

The 14th Artillery Division was granted the Guard status and became the 4th Guards Heavy Cannon Artillery Division in June 1943.
Form the 18th and 28th Artillery Divisions in Leningrad.
This decision will give you access to Red Army artillery units.

The 18th and 28th Artillery Divisions were assembled in Leningrad in early 1943. Both units participated in the siege of the city, before being upgraded into the 18th and 28th Breakthrough Artillery Divisions in May 1943 and October 1944 respectively.
Form the 7th and 9th Breakthrough Artillery Divisions.
This decision will give you access to Red Army artillery units.
The 7th and 9th Breakthrough Artillery Divisions were set up in the South Western Front in August 1943, by upgrading the former 7th and 9th Artillery Divisions.
Form the 13th and 15th Breakthrough Artillery Divisions.
This decision will give you access to Red Army artillery units.

In May 1943, Stavka started the upgrade of its Artillery Divisions, giving them more firepower. The new 'Breakthrough' or 'Shock' Artillery Divisions (in Russian, Proryva) received up to 6 artillery brigades, each made of 2 artillery regiments. The standard composition was:
1 light artillery brigade (76mm)
2 cannon artillery brigades (122 to 152mm)
2 howitzer artillery brigades
1 mortar artillery brigade.
No fewer than 14 divisions were upgraded from May to July 1943. The 13th and 15th Breakthrough Artillery Divisions were the first to be set up.
Form the 3rd Breakthrough Artillery Corps.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army Artillery Corps.
3rd Breakthrough Artillery Corps was set up in May 1943 and placed under the command of General Nikolai N. Zhdanov. It was in command of the 18th and 23rd Breakthrough Artillery Divisions.
Form the 7th Breakthrough Artillery Corps.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army Artillery Corps.

7th Breakthrough Artillery Corps was set up in May 1943 and placed under the command of General Pavel M. Korolkov. It was in command of the 16th and the freshly formed 17th Breakthrough Artillery Divisions.
Form the 4th Breakthrough Artillery Corps.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army Artillery Corps.
4th Breakthrough Artillery Corps was set up in June 1943 and placed under the command of General Nikolai V. Ignatov. It was in command of the 5th and 12th Breakthrough Artillery Divisions.
Form the 5th Breakthrough Artillery Corps.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army Artillery Corps.
5th Breakthrough Artillery Corps was set up in June 1943 and placed under the command of General Mikhail P. Kuteinikov. It was in command of the 20th and 22nd Breakthrough Artillery Divisions.
Form the 8th Breakthrough Artillery Corps.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army Artillery Corps.
8th Breakthrough Artillery Corps was set up in July 1943 and placed under the command of General Nikolai F. Salichko. It was in command of the 3rd and 6th Breakthrough Artillery Divisions.
Form the 8th Cannon Artillery Division.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army artillery unit.
The 8th Cannon Artillery Division was created in October 1943 and assigned to the Baltic Front. It remained there for the duration of the war.
Form the 2nd Breakthrough Artillery Division.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army artillery unit.

The 2nd Breakthrough Artillery Division was set up in April 1944 from the 2nd Artillery Division. It was attached to General Vladimir Z. Romanovskii's 67th Army in Leningrad.\n\n§RNote for player: Due to the 7 brigade per unit limitation, extra artillery brigades are here attached to the aforementioned army.§W
Form the 10th Breakthrough Artillery Division.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army artillery unit.
The 10th Breakthrough Artillery was set up in August 1944 from the the 10th Artillery Division. It was attached to General Aleksandr A. Luchinski's 28th Army in Orel.
Form the 1st Breakthrough Artillery Corps.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army Artillery Corps.

In October 1944, 5 new artillery corps were raised, using mostly new formations.\n1st Breakthrough Artillery Corps was set up in Moscow in October 1944, taking command of the 24th and 25th Breakthrough Artillery Divisions.
Form the 2nd Breakthrough Artillery Corps.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army Artillery Corps.
2nd Breakthrough Artillery Corps was set up in Kharkov in October 1944. The 1st and 28th Breakthrough Artillery Divisions were placed under the command of General Gleb K. Diashan.
Form the 6th Breakthrough Artillery Corps.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army Artillery Corps.
6th Breakthrough Artillery Corps was set up in Smolensk in October 1944. It was made up of the 14th and 29th Breakthrough Artillery Divisions, which were also completely fresh units.
Form the 9th Breakthrough Artillery Corps.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army Artillery Corps.
General N.N Zhdanov took command of the 9th Breakthrough Artillery Corps in Orel in October 1944. Like the 2nd and 6th Corps, it was a completely new formation.
Form the 10th Breakthrough Artillery Corps.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army Artillery Corps.

10th Breakthrough Artillery Corps was the last artillery corps cretaed by the Stavka in October 1944. General Leonid I. Kozhirov was in command of this formation, made up of 2 fresh units: The 14th and 31st Breakthrough Artillery Divisions.
Form the 1st Tank Army.
This decision will give you access to a Tank Army HQ.

1st Tank Army was formed for the first time on July 26th, 1942 on the Stalingrad Front to take command of the 13th and 28th Tank Corps. Its commander was General Mikhail E. Katukov.
Second formation happened on February 7th, 1943 on the South Western Front. At this time, the 1st Tank Army was in charge of 6th Tank Corps, 3rd Mechanized Corps and the 112th Tank Brigade 'Revolutionary Mongolia'.

It was granted the Guards status on April 25th, 1944 becoming the 1st Guards Tank Army.
Form the 2nd Tank Army.
This decision will give you access to a Tank Army HQ.

2nd Tank Army was formed on January 15th, 1943 on the Bryansk Front, from the staff of 3rd Reserve Army. Under command of General Aleksei G. Rodin, this force included 11th and 16th Tank Corps, 11th Guards Tank Brigade and other infantry and artillery assets.\n\nEventually it was renamed as 2nd Guards Tank Army on November 20th, 1944.
Form the 3rd Tank Army.
This decision will give you access to a Tank Army HQ.

3rd Tank Army was set up on May 26th, 1942on the Bryansk Front, upon the staff of From 58th Army and placed under command of General Pavel S. Rybalko. 3rd Tank Army was composed of 12th and 15th Tank Corps associated with the 179th Separate Tank Brigade.\n\nIt was granted the Guards Status on May 14th, 1943 becoming the 3rd Guards Tank Army.
Form the 4th Tank Army.
This decision will give you access to a Tank Army HQ.

4th Tank Army was set up for the first time on August 1st, 1942 upon the staff of 28th Army. Its commander was General Vasilii M. Badanov and the army was in command of 22nd and 23rd Tank Corps assisted by the 133 Tank Brigade. A second formation occured on July 1st, 1943 in Moscow to take command of various formations including the 5th and 6th Guards Mechanized Corps.\n\nEventually it was granted the Guards status on March 17th, 1945, becoming the 4th Guards Tank Army.
Form the 5th Tank Army.
This decision will give you access to a Tank Army HQ.

5th Tank Army was formed twice.\nFirst formation happened on June 5th, 1942 in the Moscow Military District, to take command of of 2nd, 7th and 11th Tank Corps, assisted by the 19th Independant Tank Brigade.\nSecond formation occured on September 3rd, 1942 on the Bryansk Front. This time, General Pavel S. Rybalko was in charge of 1st 22nd and 26th Tank Corps. It was later disbanded with its staff assigned to the 12th Army.
Form the 6th Tank Army.
This decision will give you access to a Tank Army HQ.

Andrei G. Kravchenko's 6th Tank Army was the last Tank Army formed during the war. It was set up on the 1st Ukrainian Front on January 25th, 1944 gathering 5th Guards Tank Corps and 5th Mechanized Corps.\n\nIn September 1944, it was granted the Guards status, becoming the 6th Guards Tank Army.
NKVD Troops.
This decision will give access to NKVD historical units.

The People's Commissariat for Internal Affairs (NKVD) was controlling a vast security force, from the Border Guards to prisons, railways and industrial installations. In June 1941, the NKVD started to form combat units to provide security behind the front, and sometimes fill the gaps.\n\n§RNote for player: this will allow you to form some Rifle and Motorized Divisions from the already existing security units, at some IC/resources costs.§W
GUVV NKVD.
This decision will give access to an NKVD HQ.

The Main Directorate of Internal Troops of the NKVD (Glavnoie Upravlenie Vnutrennikh Voisk NKVD, GUVV NKVD) was set up on January 19th 1942, to take command of all the Internal Fighting Troops of the NKVD.
From the OMSDON.
This decision will give access to a NKVD Special Forces unit.

The 1st Special Purpose NKVD Division (OMSDON) got various names in history. It was raised in 1921 as the OSNAZ ("Special Purpose Detachment"), including the 1st Separate Regiment of the GPU supported by one armored regiment. Renamed DON ("Special Purpose Division") in 1924 and totalling 4 rifle regiments, it changed once again in 1926, being designated the "Special Purpose Division named after F.E. Dzerjinski". This division conducted the suppression of various rebellions in the late 20s and early 30s in the Don, Tambov and Central Asian areas.\n\nOn September 8th 1937, it was renamed the "Separate Motorized Rifle Division for Special Purpose (OMSDON) named after F.E. Dzerzhinsky of the NKVD troops."
Upgrade the OMSDON.
This decision will upgrade an NKVD unit.

On February 14th 1943, after the transfer of some elements to a second unit, the OMSDON was renamed "1st Motorized Rifle Order of Lenin Special Purpose Division named after F.E. Dzerzhinsky of the NKVD of USSR", also known as 1st MSDN (Motorized Special Purpose Division).
Form a second OMSDON unit.
This decision will give access to a second NKVD Special Forces unit.
On January 4th 1942, mobile elements of the OMSDON were transferred to create a second unit, later renamed the 2nd MSDN (Motorized Special Purpose Division).
Form 2 NKVD Rifle Divisions.
This decision will give access to NKVD units.

In September 1941, 2 NKVD Rifle Divisions were assembled in the Leningrad Military District using men and weapons of some Border Guards and other security units.

The 1st NKVD Rifle Division was raised in Vaskelovo, north of Leningrad. It was transferred in August 1942 to the Red Army as the 46th Rifle Division.
The 20th NKVD Rifle Division was raised in Leningrad from the former 20th NKVD Division for important industrial enterprises. It was also transferred to the Red Army in August 1942, as the 92nd Rifle Division.
Form 4 more NKVD Rifle Divisions.
This decision will give access to NKVD units.

In January 1942, 4 more NKVD Rifle Divisions were raised to secure rear areas behind the frontline:

The 5th NKVD Rifle Division was raised in Tikhvin (Volkov Front).
The 6th NKVD Rifle Division was raised in Kalinin (North Western Front).
The 10th NKVD Rifle Division was raised in Stalingrad and became the 181st Stalingrad Order of Lenin Rifle Division in February 1943.
The 11th NKVD Rifle Division was raised in Krasnodar (Southern Front).
Form 5 more NKVD Rifle Divisions.
This decision will give access to NKVD units.

As the Axis approached the Caucasus in summer 1942, the NKVD raised 5 more divisions from Georgian, Armenian and Azerbaijani Border Guards and other assets spread throughout the Caucasus, like cavalry or mountain troops.
Form NKVD Motor Rifle Divisions.
This decision will give access to NKVD units.

At the outbreak of hostilities with Germany, the NKVD raised an emergency 3 motorized divisions and 1 motorized brigade, all lacking in support units.

The 21st NKVD Motor Rifle Division was raised in Leningrad on July 1st 1941, and was later converted into the 109th Rifle Division.

The 22nd NKVD Motor Rifle Division was raised in Riga on June 23rd 1941.

The 23rd NKVD Motor Rifle Division was raised in Kiev on June 26th 1941. Remnants of both units served to form the 4th NKVD Motor Rifle Division on January 5th 1942.

The 76th NKVD Motor Rifle Brigade was raised in Tbilisi on August 15th 1941.
Reorganize our NKVD motorized units.
This decision will reorganize some NKVD units.

In January 1942, the NKVD reorganized its motorized units, which had been severely exhausted, filling the gaps with all remaining elements like Border Guards. 4 new units (The 4th, 7th, 8th and 9th NKVD Motor Rifle Divisions) were created in Leningrad, Tula, Voronezh and Rostov.

In January 1942, the NKVD reorganized its motorized units, which had been severely exhausted, filling the gaps with all remaining elements like Border Guards. 4 new units (The 4th, 7th, 8th and 9th NKVD Motor Rifle Divisions) were created in Leningrad, Tula, Voronezh and Rostov.\n\n§RNote for player: if one of the previous cities is already lost at this time, units will spawn in Kuybyshev.§W
Form the 13th NKVD Motorized Rifle Division.
This decision will give access to an NKVD unit.

In May 1942, the 8th NKVD Motor Rifle Division was split to form the 36th Rifle Division alongside a new NKVD Motor Rifle Division numbered the 13th.\nThe 13th NKVD Motor Rifle Division became the 95th Rifle Division in August 1942.\nThe 36th Rifle Division later became the 52nd Guards Rifle Division.
Transfer troops from the NKVD to the Red Army.
This decision will upgrade some NKVD units to Red Army standards.

In August 15th 1942, some NKVD who distinguished themselves in combat were transferred from the GUVV NKVD to the Red Army.

The 1st NKVD Infantry Division, formed in Leningrad, became the 46th Rifle Division.
The 3rd NKVD Rifle Division, combined with the 21st NKVD Motor Rifle Division, became the 109th Rifle Division.
The 9th NKVD Motor Rifle Division became the 31st Rifle Division.
The 20th NKVD Infantry Division was renamed the 92nd Rifle Division.
The 13th NKVD Motor Rifle Division, raised in Stalingrad, was renamed the 95th Rifle Division and later became the 75th Guards Rifle Division.
70th NKVD Army.
This decision will give access to Red Army units.

The formation of the 70th Separate Army of NKVD Troops started in October 1942. It was composed of 6 Rifle Divisions assembled with NKVD Border and Railroad Security units, from October 1942 to February 1943. Units were assembled in the Far Eastern, Transbaikal, Central Asia, Siberian and Ural Military Districts, with the addition of the experienced 10th NKVD Stalingrad Rifle Division.
In February 1943, 70th Army was transferred to Red Army control and all its units were converted to Rifle Divisions with Red Army TOE. This army played an important role during the battle of Kursk.

§RNote for player: the formation of NKVD divisions will be skipped for game purposes and you'll get the 70th as it was when transferred to the Red Army.§W
Form the 8th Estonian Rifle Corps.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army Corps.

The 8th Estonian Rifle Corps was formed from mobilized ethnic Estonians, incorporating former personnel of the Republic of Estonia's army. It was subordinated to the Kalinin Front by December 1st 1942. The corps structure consisted of the 7th and 249th Rifle Divisions stationed in Estonia, reinforced by volunteers from the Estonian Communist Party organisation. In an effort to increase overall formation experience, the battle-hardened 19th Guards Rifle Division later joined the 8th Rifle Corps. Throughout its entire existence, the rifle corps was commanded by Lieutenant General Lembit Pärn. On September 22nd 1944, elements of the 7th Rifle Division, along with the 45th Estonian Tank Regiment, formed the forward detachment of the corps and entered Tallinn, for which all three units received the name of that city as a battle honor.
Form the 1st Polish Rifle Division.
This decision will give you access to allied forces from foreign countries.

The 1st Polish 'Tadeusz Kosciuszko' Infantry Division was the bulk of the communist-led Polish forces fighting alongside the Soviet Union, becoming, in the later stages of the war, the Polish People's Army (Ludowe Wojsko Polskie). This army was known as Berling's Army, one of its founders, to distinguish it from Anders'Army, fighting with the Western Allies. Troops were recruited from former Polish POWs and, later on, the liberated Polish terriories. Due to the lack of officers, many of them were transferred from the Red Army.\nThe 1st Polish Infantry Division was created in May 1943 and became operational in September, participating in its first major engagement at the Battle of Lenino.
Form the 1st Polish Corps.
This decision will give you access to allied forces from foreign countries.

Polish forces were rapidly strengthened to 30,000 troops force with armored assets like the 1st Armored Brigade, artillery support and aircraft, forming the 1st Polish Corps (1 Korpus Polskich Sil Zbrojnych w ZSRR). In March 1943, it was redesignated as the 1st Polish Army.\n\n§RNote for player: You'll have to manuall attach the 1st Polish Rifle Division to this corps.§W
Form the 1st Polish Army.
This decision will give you access to allied forces from foreign countries.

Formed in March 1944 from the 1st Polish Corps, the 1st Polish Army (1. Armia Wojska Polskiego) was attached to the 1st Bielorussian Front and participated in the main offensives against Axis forces in 1944 and 1945, including the Vistula, Warsaw, Kolberg and Berlin offensives. At this stage of the war, the Polish role in the Soviet drive westward was fairly substantial, contributing 200,000 troops. This was approximately ten percent of the force taking part in Zhukov's and Konev's drive on Berlin.\n\n§RNote for player: You'll have to manually attach the 1st Polish Corps to this Army.§W
Form the 2nd Polish Army.
This decision will give you access to allied forces from foreign countries.

Formed in late 1944, the Polish 2nd Army (2. Armia Wojska Polskiego) was made of 4 infantry divisions and the 16th Tank Brigade. It was placed under the command of General Karol K. Sverchevskii. This force participated in the battle of Bautzen, where it suffered heavy losses, before being involved in the last great Soviet offensive of the war, the drive on Prague.\n2nd Polish Army used recruits from the recently liberated Polish territories but lacked officers, forcing the Red Army to fill the gaps with 50% of them. This situation led to the cancellation of the creation of a 3rd Polish Army and a Polish Front.
Reinforce the 2nd Polish Army.
This decision will give you access to allied forces from foreign countries.
In February 1945, 2nd Polish Army got some reinforcements, including the 10th Polish Rifle Division, an artillery division and a SU-85 Mobile artillery regiment.
Form Romanian volunteers divisions.
This decision will give you access to allied forces from foreign countries.

In late 1943, Soviet Union incorporated Romanian POWs and Romanian Communists into 2 new units fighting alongside the Red Army.

The 1st Romanian Volunteer Division "Tudor Vladimirescu" named after the leader of the Wallachian uprising of 1821, was assembled in Ryazan at the end of 1943 but entered in active service in March 1944 and was placed under the command of General Nicola Cambria. It was basically an infantry division using captured German armor like the renamed T-5 'Pantera' (Pz.Kpfw. V Panther).
The 2nd Romanian Volunteer Division "Horia, Closca si Crisan" was raised later. It didn't take part in frontline combat and served as a security force against pro-Axis Romanians in the newly liberated Romania.
The two communist divisions were integrated into the Romanian Army on August 22nd 1945.
Form a French Volunteers Air Regiment.
This decision will give you access to allied forces from foreign countries.

GC3 'Normandie Niemen' was an fighter unit made of Free French who were sent to the Soviet Union to fight Germany alongside the Soviet Union. After long and tedious negociations between French and Soviet officials, a small group of French pilots and mechanics arrived in Russia in late 1942, and it was decided that they will fly Soviet fighters - the Yak-1 and later Yak-3.

Assigned to the 6th Air Regiment of the 1st Soviet Air Army, GC3 'Normandie' fought its first campaign (March 1943 - November 1943) before being converted into a full air regiment for the later stages of the war. In June 1945, a Stalin Decree gave the French pilots permission to return to their conuntry with their planes. From 1943 to 1945, 'Normandie Niemen' flew over 5240 combat missions, getting 273 confirmed kills for the loss of 38 KIA or MIA.

Many French pilots distinguished themselves in this unit, notably the unlikely tandem of Marcel Albert (23 kills) and Roland de la Poype (16 kills), one from a humble worker's background and the other from an aristocratic family.
Mongolian People's Republic sends some help.
This decision will give you access to ressources from you allied.

As a result of the Mutual Assistance Pact of March 12th, 1936 and the involvement of Soviet forces in the Battle of Khalkin Gol (Summer 1939), Mongolia provided supplies and raw materials to the Soviet military during WW2. From June 1941, until the end of 1945, the USSR imported from Mongolia 0.7 million heads of cattle, 4.9 million heads of small cattle, 0.5 million military horses, almost 6 million pieces of small leather.
By February 1942, Vneshtorgbank of the USSR received funding from the MPR for the construction of tanks, estimated to a total of 3.8 million rubles. In January 1943, Marshal Horloogiyn Choibalsan led a delegation of the MPR into Soviet Union for the gift of Mongolina funded tank column made of 34 T-34/76 and 21 T-70 tanks. They were transfered to the 112th Tank Brigade, renamed as the '112th Red Banner Tank Brigade Revolutionary Mongolia'.
In March 1943, following the presentation of the 'Revolutionary Mongolia' tank brigade to the Red Army, MPR officials announced their intention to fund a fighter squadron within the Soviet Air Force. The squadron was given 12 Lavochkin La-5 fighters in a formal ceremony and formed part of the 2nd Guards Fighter Aviation Regiment.
Also, more than 300 Mongolian volunteer military personnel fought in the Eastern front while Mongolia kept 10% of its population under arms...

Under Operation Zet, the Soviets provided China with warplanes, bombers, tanks, antiaircraft weapons, ammunition, and transport vehicles. An estimated total of 82 T-26 tanks, 700 cars, 240 field guns, 20 anti-aircraft guns, 430 small-caliber guns and about 2 million shells to them, 300 machine guns, 3 600 handguns, more than 4,000,000 rifle cartridges were delivered. The operation began with the deployment of 225 combat aircraft, along with Soviet volunteers. Between 1937 and 1941, more than 4000 military personnel were involved in the operation.\n\n§ROur glorious volunteers are back and waiting you ordres in Irkoutsk.§W
Get the benefits from Operation Zet.
This decision will give you access to bonuses in air warfare.

A large part of the help sent by Soviet Union to China during Operation Zet concerned air power. About 500 aircrafts were delivered, among them were 6 TB-3, 146 SB, 109 I-16, 8 UTI-4, and 222 I-15. Soviet pilots of the Volunteer Group flew combat missions, especially bombing runs over Nanjing, Taiwan and even over Japan Islands where a TB-3 group, led by the mixed Soviet-Chinese crew drop leaflets. Although Soviet bombers performed well, fighters like I-15 and I-16 had a bad time against Japanese fighters, especially from September 1940 when IJN deployed the Mitsubishi A-6M Zero.\n\n§ROur glorious volunteers are back and waiting you ordres in Irkoutsk.§W

Form 1st Guards Cavalry Corps.

2nd Cavalry Corps was granted the Guards status, becoming the 1st Guards Cavalry Corps in late November 1941. This corps was placed under the command of General Pavel I. Belov. The 5th and 9th Cavalry Divisions became the 1st and 2nd Guards Cavalry Divisions.\n\n§RNote for player: this corps will be upgraded in January 1943.§W
Form 2nd Guards Cavalry Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army Guards corps.

3rd Cavalry Corps under General Lev M. Dovator was granted the Guards status in late November 1941, becoming the 2nd Guards Cavalry Corps, in command of the 20th Mountain Cavalry Division and the 3rd and 4th Guards Cavalry Divisions formed from the already existing 50th and 55th Cavalry Divisions.\n\n§RNote for player: this corps will be upgraded in October 1943.§W
Form the 3rd Guards Cavalry Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army Guards corps.

5th Cavalry Corps was granted the Guards status in December 1941 and renamed 3rd Guards Cavalry Corps. Placed under the command of General Vasilii D. Kriuchenkin, this corps was composed of the former 3rd and 14th Cavalry Divisions, renamed 5th and 6th Guards Cavalry Divisions, and the 32nd Cavalry Division.\n\n§RNote for player: this unit will be upgraded in September 1943.§W
Form the 4th Guards Cavalry Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army Guards corps.

In August 1942 the former 17th Cavalry Corps (12th, 13th and 30th Cavalry Divisions) was granted the Guards status, becoming the 4th Guards Corps. Placed under the command of General Nikolai I. Kirichenko and assembled in Maïkop, it was in command of 9th and 10th Guards Cavalry Divisions and the 30th Cavalry Division.\n\n§RNote for player: this unit will be upgraded in September 1943.§W
Form the 5th Guards Cavalry Corps.
This decision will give access to a Red Army Guards corps.

5th Guards Don Cossack Cavalry Corps was set up in Dagestan in November 1942 and placed under the command of General Aleksei G. Selivanov. It was created from the former 15th and 116th Cavalry Divisions who became the 11th and 12th Guards Cavalry Divisions respectively, assisted by the 63rd Cavalry Division.\n\n§RNote for player: this unit will be upgraded in August 1943.§W
Form the 6th Guards Cavalry Corps.
This decision will give access to Red Army Guards corps.

6th Guards Cavalry Corps was formed in February 1943 by granting the Guards status to the 7th Cavalry Corps (11th Cavalry Division and 83rd Mountain Cavalry Division). Its commander was General Sergei V. Sokolov.
Form the 7th Guards Cavalry Corps.
This decision will give access to Red Army Guards corps.

7th Guards Cavalry Corps was the last Guards cavalry corps to be formed in February 1943, by granting Guards status to the 8th Cavalry Corps (21st Mountain Cavalry Division, 55th Cavalry Division and 112th Cavalry Division). It was placed under the command of General Mikhail D. Borisov.
Upgrade the 1st Guards Cavalry Corps.
This decision will upgrade a Red Army Guards Corps.

In January 1943, 1st Guards Cavalry Corps, now placed under the command of General Viktor K. Baranov, was reinforced by the addition of the 7th Guards Cavalry Division and various support assets like self-propelled rocket artillery, self-propelled artillery and tank destroyers.

1st Guards Motorized Division.
This decision will give access to a Red Army Guards unit.

The 1st Guards Motor Rifle Division was formed in Mozhaysk (Moscow Military District) on September 21st 1941, by granting the Guards status to the former Moscow Motor Rifle Division. Part of the 7th Mechanized Corps, it was the first formation to use T-34s againt the enemy at Borisov, on June 30th 1941. After a first annihilation, it was recreated under the name of 1st Tank Division, and later 1st Guards Motor Rifle Division.\n\nIn January 1943, it was renamed to the 1st Guards Rifle Division (second formation) as the previous 1st Guards Rifle Division had been used to form the 1st Guards Mechanized Corps.
2nd Guards Motorized Division.
This decision will give access to a Red Army Guards unit.
The 2nd Guards Motor Rifle Division was set up in Moscow from the 107th Motor Rifle Division on January 12th 1942. It became the 49th Guards Rifle Division in October 1942.
Form the 3rd Guards Motorized Division.
This decision will give access to a Red Army Guards unit.
The 3rd Guards Motor Rifle Division was set up on March 17th 1942 in Mozhaysk on the basis of the 82nd Motor Rifle Division. In June 1943, it was used to form the 6th Guards Mechanized Corps.
First Guards Rifle Divisions!
This decision will give access to Red Army Guards units.

In September 1941, Stavka started to attribute the title of "Guards" to units of the Red Army that distinguished themselves during the war. Guards status was more than just a decoration and had practical benefits for those in such units: enlisted personnel in Guards units received double pay compared to those in other units, and non-commissioned officers and above received 1.5 times the pay of their counterparts in other units. Such rewards meant that it often acted as a morale booster and increased unit cohesion. Guards status also resulted in higher priority for replacements and equipment than normal units.

A first batch of 3 Guards Rifle divisions was attributed on September 18th 1941 to units in the Moscow vicinity.

The 1st Guards Order of Lenin Rifle Division was formed by renaming the 100th Rifle Division.

The 2nd Guards Taman Rifle Division was formed by renaming the 127th Rifle Division.

The 5th Guards Gorodok Rifle Division was formed by renaming the 107th Rifle Division.
3rd and 4th Guards Rifle Divisions.
This decision will give access to Red Army Guards units.
Both the 3rd and 4th Guards Rifle Divisions were set up in Leningrad on September 18th 1941, by renaming the former 153rd and 161st Rifle Divisions.
6th and 7th Guards Rifle Divisions.
This decision will give access to Red Army Guards units.
The 6th and 7th Guards Rifle divisions were set up in Bryansk on September 26th 1941 and placed under the command of the 1st Guards Special Rifle Corps of General D.D. Lelyushenko.
8th and 9th Guards Rifle Divisions.
This decision will give access to Red Army Guards units.
The 8th and 9th Guards Rifle Divisions were set up in Moscow in November 1941, by renaming the 316th and 78th Rifle Divisions respectively.
10th Guards Rifle Division.
This decision will give access to a Red Army Guards unit.

The 10th Guards Rifle Division was formed on December 26th 1941 by renaming the 52nd Rifle Division. In March 1942, a second and last Guards Rifle Division - the 23rd - was also set up, both in the polar city of Murmansk.
Form the 11th, 12th and 13th Guards Rifle Divisions.
This decision will give access to Red Army Guards units.

The 11th, 12th and 13th Guards Rifle Divisions were set up in the Moscow and Bryansk areas in early January 1942, by renaming the 18th Moscow Militia Division, 258th Rifle Divison and 87th Rifle Division respectively.
Form the 14th and 15th Guards Rifle Divisions.
This decision will give access to Red Army Guards units.
The 14th and 15th Guards Rifle Divisions were set up in the Southern Front in late January 1942, by renaming the 96th Mountain Divison and 136th Rifle Division respectively.
Form the 16th, 18th, 20th and 21st Guards Rifle Divisions.
This decision will give access to Red Army Guards units.

In February and March 1942, 4 more rifle divisions were granted the Guards status, in the Moscow Military District:

The 249th Rifle Division became the 16th Guards Rifle Division.
The 133rd Rifle Division became the 18th Guards Rifle Division.
The 174th Rifle Division became the 20th Guards Rifle Division.
The 361st Rifle Division became the 21st Guards Rifle Division.
Form the 17th, 19th, 22nd, 24th and 25th Guards Rifle Divisions.
This decision will give access to Red Army Guards units.

In March and April 1942, 5 more rifle divisions were granted the Guards status, on the Kalinin Front:

The 119th Rifle Division became the 17th Guards Rifle Division.
The 366th Rifle Division became the 19th Guards Rifle Division.
The 363rd Rifle Division became the 22nd Guards Rifle Divisio.
The 111th Rifle Division became the 24th Guards Rifle Division.
The 2nd Guards Rifle Brigade became the 25th Guards Rifle Division.
Form the 23rd Guards Rifle Division.
This decision will give access to a Red Army Guards unit.
The 23rd Guards Rifle Division was set up by giving the Guards status to the 88th Rifle Division in March 1942, on the Murmansk Front.
Form the 26th, 27th, 28th and 29th Guards Rifle Divisions.
This decision will give access to Red Army Guards units.

In late April and May 1942, 4 more rifle divisions were granted the Guards status, on the Western Front:

The 93rd Rifle Division became the 26th Guards East Siberian Rifle Division.
The 3rd Guards Rifle Brigade became the 27th Guards Rifle Division.
The 180th Rifle Division, from the former 22nd Territorial Corps raised in Estonia, became the 28th Guards Rifle Division.
The 32nd Rifle Division became the 29th Guards Rifle Division.
Form the 30th and 31st Guards Rifle Divisions.
This decision will give access to Red Army Guards units.
The 30th and 31st Guards Rifle Division were formed from the 238th and 328th Rifle Divisions, on the Bryansk Front in May 1942.
Form the 32nd and 33rd Guards Rifle Divisions.
This decision will give access to Red Army Guards units.

Stavka started in May 1942 to give the Guards status to paratrooper units that distinguished themselves from the beginning of the war.

The 32nd 'Taman' Guards Rifle Division was formed on May 14th in the Taman Peninsula from the 2nd Airborne Corps.
The 33rd Guards Rifle Division was formed the same day in the Volga Military District, from the 3rd Airborne Corps.
Form the 34th, 36th, 37th and 38th Guards Rifle Divisions.
This decision will give access to Red Army Guards units.

In August 1942, Stavka turned its airborne corps into Guards divisions on the Western Front:

The 34th Guards Rifle Division was formed from the former 7th Airborne Corps on August 29th 1942, in the Moscow Military District.
The 36th Guards Rifle Division was formed from the former 9th Airborne Corps in Ivanovo.
The 37th 'Rechitsa' Guards Rifle Division was formed from the former 1st Airborne Corps on August 2nd 1942, in Lyubertsy. It was transferred to the Southern Front and defended the Stalingrad Tractor Factory during the battle of Stalingrad, suffering 95% losses.
The 38th Guards Rifle Division was formed from the former 4th Airborne Corps in the Moscow Military District.
Form the 35th, 39th, 40th and 41st Guards Rifle Divisions.
This decision will give access to Red Army Guards units.

In August 1942, Stavka turned its airborne corps into Guards divisions on the Stalingrad Front:

The 35th Guards Rifle Division was formed from the former 8th Airborne Corps.
The 39th Guards Rifle Division was formed from the former 5th Airborne Corps.
The 40th Guards Rifle Division was formed from the former 6th Airborne Corps.
The 41st Guards Rifle Division was formed from the former 10th Airborne Corps.
Form the 42rd, 47th, 48th and 49th Guards Rifle Divisions.
This decision will give access to Red Army Guards units.

In October 1942, 4 more Guards rifle divisions were formed from former units on the Western Front:

The 42nd Guards Rifle Division was formed from the former 1st Guards Rifle Brigade.
The 47th Guards Rifle Division was formed from the former 154th Rifle Division.
The 48th Guards Rifle Division was formed from the former 264th Rifle Division (second formation).
The 49th Guards Rifle Division was formed by converting the former 2nd Guards Motor Rifle Division.
Form the 43rd, 45th and 46th Guards Rifle Divisions.
This decision will give access to Red Army Guards units.

Still in October 1942, 3 more units were granted the Guards status in the Northwestern Front:

The 201st Rifle Division became the 43rd Latvian Guards Rifle Division.
The 70th Rifle Division became the 45th Guards Rifle Division.
The 174th Rifle Division (second formation) became the 46th Guards Rifle Division.
Form the 44th Guards Rifle Division.
This decision will give access to Red Army Guards units.
On October 5th 1942, on the Stalingrad Front, the 5th Rifle Division was granted the Guards Status and was renamed the 44th Guards Rifle Division.
Form the 50th, 51st and 52nd Guards Rifle Divisions.
This decision will give access to Red Army Guards units.

In November 1942, 3 more divisions were granted the Guards status in the Southwestern and Southern Fronts:

The 124th Rifle Division (second formation) became the 50th Guards Rifle Division, in Voronezh.
The 76th Rifle Division, the former Armenian Moutain Division became the 51st Guards Rifle Division, in Stalingrad.
The 63rd Rifle Division, the former 8th NKVD Motorized Rifle Division, became the 52nd Guards Rifle Division, in Stalingrad.
Form the 53rd, 54th, 55th, 57th and 58th Guards Rifle Divisions.
This decision will give access to Red Army Guards units.

In the second half of December 1942, 5 more divisions were granted the Guards status in the Northwestern Front and Moscow Military District:

The 130th Rifle Division became the 53rd Guards Rifle Division.
The 119th Rifle Division (second formation) became the 54th Guards Rifle Division.
The 30th Rifle Division became the 55th Guards Rifle Division.
The 153rd Rifle Division became the 57th Guards Rifle Division.
The 1st Rifle Division became the 58th Guards Rifle Division.
Form the 59th, 60th, 61st, 62nd, 66th and 67th Guards Rifle Divisions.
This decision will give access to Red Army Guards units.

After the decisive victory at Stalingrad in January 1943, 6 more rifle divisions were granted the Guards status:

The 197th Rifle Division (second formation) became the 59th Guards Rifle Division.
The 278th Rifle Division became the 60th Guards Rifle Division.
The 159th Rifle Division (second formation) became the 61st Guards Rifle Division.
The 127th Rifle Division (second formation) became the 62nd Guards Rifle Division.
The 293rd Rifle Division became the 66th Guards Rifle Division.
The 304th Rifle Division became the 67th Guards Rifle Division.
Form 63rd and 64th Guards Rifle Divisions.
This decision will give access to Red Army Guards units.

The 63rd Guards Rifle Division was formed in Stalingrad from the 136th Rifle Division, former 8th Naval Rifle Brigade, in Leningrad in early 1943. It was formed alongside the 64th Guards Rifle Division, formed by renaming the 327th Rifle Division.
Form the 75th Guards Rifle Division.
This decision will give access to Red Army Guards units.
The 75th Guards Rifle Division was formed in March 1943, from the 95th Rifle Division, former 13th NKVD Motor Rifle Division. It was placed under the command of General Vasilii A. Gorishnii.
Form the 120th Guards Rifle Division.
This decision will give access to Red Army Guards units.
The 308th Rifle Division was awarded the Order of Red Banner for its actions in Stalingrad. It was also granted the Guards status, becoming the 120th Guards Rifle Division.
Form the 1st Guards Rifle Division (second formation).
This decision will give access to a Red Army Guards unit.

In late October 1942, the 1st Guards Rifle Division was used to form the 1st Guards Mechanized Corps. It was the decided to convert the 1st Guards Motorized Rifle Division into a Rifle Division, taking back the N°1. This new 1st Guards Rifle Division was set up in Moscow in January 1943 and placed under the command of General Nikolai A. Kropotin.
Form the 7th Guards Cavalry Division.
This decision will give access to a Red Army Guards unit.
7th Guards Cavalry Division was set up on January 5th, 1942 by granting the Guards status to the 31st Cavalry Division. This unit was attached to the recently formed 1st Guards Cavalry Corps.
Form the 1st Guards Tank Brigade.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army Guards unit.

After the heavy losses of Summer 1941 and the destruction of almost all its Mechanized Corps, Soviet high command was forced to rebuild new armored troops in September 1941. For example, the 4th Tank Brigade began to be built in late August 1941 upon the basis of the former 15th Tank Division and equipped with T-34 tanks from the Stalingrad Factory. On November 11th 1941, it was granted the Guards status becoming the 1st Guards Tank Brigade.\nThis brigade was later assigned to the 3rd Mechanized Corps in November 1942.
Form the 2nd Independant Guards Tank Brigade.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army Guards unit.

The 2nd Independant Guards Tank Brigade was set up on January 5th, 1942 by granting the Guards status to Ivan Kirichenko's 9th Tank Brigade. This brigade was reinforced by the 519th Flamethrower Tank Battalion and was assigned to various armies from the Western Front.
Form the 3rd Guards Tank Brigade.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army Guards unit.

On January 11th, 1942, Pavel Rotmistrov's 8th Tank Brigade was given the Guards status and became the 3rd Guards Tank Brigade.\nA few monthes later, this brigade was used to form the 7th Tank Corps and eventually the 3rd Guards Mechanized Corps.
Form the 4th Guards Tank Brigade.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army Guards unit.

4th Guards Tank Brigade was created by granting the Guards status to Grigori Kuzmin's 132nd Tank Brigade on January 24th, 1942. This unit, equipped with KV-1 heavy tanks was assigned to the 24th Tank Corps in June 1942.
Form the 5th Independant Guards Tank Brigade.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army Guards unit.

5th Independant Guards Tank Brigade was set up by granting the Guards status to Nikolai Mikhailov's 142nd Tank Brigade on January 29th, 1942. Assigned to various armies of the Southern Front, it is known as the first soviet unit to use american lend lease M4A2 tanks.
Form the 6th Independant Guards Tank Brigade.
This decision will give you access to a Red Army Guards unit.

The 1st Tank Brigade raised in September 1941 was given the Guards status on February 6th, 1942, becoming the 6th Independant Guards Tank Brigade under command of Colonel Avraam Khasim. This tank brigade was assigned to 23rd Tank Corps and later various armies in the Southern Front.

26th Tank Corps was raised in July 1942 in the Moscow Military District. After its participation in the Battle of Stalingrad, it was renamed the 1st Guards Tank Corps and placed under the command of General Aleksei G. Rodin. The 216th, 19th and 157th Tank Brigades were renamed the 15th, 16th and 17th Guards Tank Brigades respectively. The former 14th Motorized Brigade became the 1st Guards Motorized Brigade.\n\n§R1st Guards Tank Corps will be upgraded in June 1943 and January 1944 to get various support assets, including heavy tanks, rocket and self-propelled artillery, halftracks, etc.§W
Upgrade the 1st Guards Tank Corps.

1st Guards Tank Corps was upgraded in June 1943 and deployed in Kupyansk (Kharkov Oblast). The composition of the corps remained the same, but as Aleksei G. Rodin became commander of the 2nd Tank Army, he was replaced by General Mikhail F. Panov.
This time the 1st Guards Tank Corps was reinforced by addition of heavy tanks like Lend Lease Churchills, rocket and anti-tank artillery and recon assets.

The next upgrade is planned for January 1944.

1st Guards Tank Corps, attached to the 2nd Tank Army, was upgraded in January 1944 by the addition of self propelled artillery (SU-76s and SU-152s), fully mechanized infantry and transports. It participated in all the major Soviet offensives of the last stages of war, from Bagration to Berlin.

24th Tank Corps was granted the Guards status in winter 1942-1943, during Operation Uranus. It became the 2nd Guards Tank Corps under the command of Vasilii M. Badanov and later Aleksei S. Burdeinyi. Its composition remained the same all war long: the 4th, 25th and 26th Guards Tank Brigades assisted by the 4th Guard Motorized Brigade.
2nd Guards Tank Corps fought the war on the Western Front and later on the 3rd Belorussian Front.

§RFor game purposes, this corps will be deployed in its 1944 version with full artillery assets.§W

Pavel Rotmistrov's 7th Tank Corps was granted the Guards status in January 1943 and became the 3rd Guards Tank Corps.\nThe 62nd and 87th Tank Brigades became the 18th and 19th Guards Tank Brigades respectively. The 7th Motorized Brigade was renamed the 2nd Guards Motorized Brigade.\n3rd Guards Tank Corps was almost fully equipped with Lend Lease Shermans and fought the war with the 2nd, 4th and later 5th Guards Tank Army.

17th Tank Corps was granted the Guards Status in January 1943 and became the 4th Guards Tank Corps, under the command of General Pavel P. Poluboiarov. The 67th, 174th Tank Brigades and 66th Heavy Tank Brigade became the 12th, 13th and 14th Guards Tank Brigades. The 31st Motorized Rifle Brigade was renamed the 3rd Guards Motorized Brigade. 4th Guards Mechanized Corps fought most of the war within the 1st Ukrainian Front.\n\n§RFor game purposes, this corps will be deployed in its 1944 version with full artillery assets.§W

4th Tank Corps was granted the Guards Status in February 1943 for its performance during the Battle of Stalingrad. It was renamed the 5th Guards Tank Corps and remained under the command of General Andrei G. Kravchenko, its former commander. The 45th, 47th and 102nd Tank Brigades became the 20th, 21st and 22nd Guards Tank Brigades, and the 4th Motorized Rifle Brigade became the 6th Guards Motorized Brigade.
5th Guards Tank Corps was initially assigned to the Voronezh Front, before being transferred to 1st, 2nd and 3rd Ukrainian Fronts. After the drive on Prague, it was sent to the Far Eastern Front to fight Japan.

§RFor game purposes, this corps will be deployed in its 1944 version with full artillery assets.§W

12th Tank Corps was granted the Guards status in June 1943, becoming the 6th Guards Tank Corps. It was placed under the command of General Aleksei P. Panfilov. The 30th, 86th Tank Brigades and 97th Heavy Tank Brigade became the 51st, 52nd and 53rd Guards Tank Brigades, and 13th Motorized Rifle Brigade was renamed the 22nd Guards Motorized Brigade. 6th Guards Tank Corps fought all war long within the 3rd Guards Tank Army.\n\n§RFor game purposes, this corps will be deployed in its 1944 version with full artillery assets.§W

15th Tank Corps was granted the Guards status in July 1943, becoming the 7th Guards Tank Corps. It was placed under the command of General Kirill F. Suleikov. Its tank brigades (the 88th, 113th and 195th) were renamed the 54th, 55th and 56th Guards Tank Brigades and the 52nd Motorized Rifle Brigade became the 23rd Guards Tank Brigade. Like the 6th Guards Tank Corps, it fought all war long within the 3rd Guards Tank Army.\n\n§RFor game purposes, this corps will be deployed in its 1944 version with full artillery assets.§W

2nd Tank Corps was granted the Guards status in September 1943 and became the 8th Guards Tank Corps. General Aleksei F. Popov remained its commander until the end of the war. The 26th, 99th and 169th Tank Brigades were renamed the 58th, 59th and 60th Guards Tank Brigades, and the 58th Motorized Rifle Brigade became the 28th Guards Motorized Brigade. 8th Tank Corps was equipped with Soviet armor (T-34s, IS-2s, SU-85s) but also had a good amount of Lend Lease M4 Shermans. It was assigned to the first and later 2nd Belorussian Fronts and ended the war participating in the Berlin Offensive.\n\n§RFor game purposes, this corps will be deployed in its 1944 version with full artillery assets.§W.

3rd Tank Corps was granted the Guards Status in late 1943 and became the 9th Guards Tank Corps. General Nikolai D. Vedeneev remained its commander until the end of the war. The 50th and 51st Tank Brigades and the 103rd Heavy Tank were renamed the 47th, 50th and 65th Guards Tank Brigades. The 57th Motor Rifle Brigade became the 33rd Guards Motor Rifle Brigade. 9th Guards Tank Corps fought the war within the 2nd Guards Tank Army.

30th Volunteer Ural Tank Corps was granted the Guards status in October 1943 and became 10th Guards Ural Tank Corps. General Evtikhii E. Belov became its commander. The 197th, 243rd and 244th Tank Brigades were renamed the 61st, 62nd and 63rd Guards Tank Brigades, and the 30th Motorized Rifle Brigade became the 29th Guards Motorized Brigade. 10th Guards Ural Tank Corps was attached to the 4th Tank Army, renamed to 4th Guards Tank Army in March 1945.\n\n§RThis unit will be upgraded in January 1945 with better assets.§W

6th Tank Corps was granted the Guards status in September 1943 and became 11th Guards Tank Corps. General Andrei L. Getman remained its commander. The 22nd, 112th and 200th Tank Brigades were renamed the 40th, 44th and 45th Guards Tank Brigades, and the 6th Motorized Rifle Brigade became the 27th Guards Motorized Brigade. 11th Guards Tank Corps was assigned to 1st Tank Army, renamed to 1st Guards Tank Army in May 1944.

16th Tank Corps was granted the Guards status in November 1944, becoming the 12th Guards Tank Corps. Its commander was General Nikolai M. Teliakov. The 107th, 109th and 164th Tank Brigades were renamed the 48th, 49th and 66th Guards Tank Brigades, while the 15th Motorized Rifle Brigade became the 34th Guards Motorized Brigade. Instead of the usual equipment of SU-76 self propelled artillery, this corps had medium tank destroyers like the SU-100 and Lend Lease M10. 12th Guards Tank Corps was assigned to the 2nd Guards Tank Army until the end of the war.

1st Guards Mechanized Corps was set up in November 1942 in the Volga Military District and placed under the command of General Ivan N. Russianov. Regiments of the 1st Guards Rifle Division were used to form the 1st, 2nd and 3rd Guards Mechanized Brigades.\n\n§RNote for player: this mechanized formation will be upgraded in January 1944 with the addition of a complete Guards Tank Brigade and various support assets.§W

2nd Guards Mechanized Corps was set up in November 1942 in the Moscow Military District and placed under the command of General Karp V. Sviridov. Regiments of the 22nd Guards Rifle Division were used to form the 4th, 2th and 6th Guards Mechanized Brigades.\n\n§RNote for player: this mechanized formation will be upgraded in January 1944 with the addition of a complete Guards Tank Brigade and various support assets.§W

Obukhov replaced V.T. Volskii and the corps was assigned to the Baltic Front and later transferred to the 1st Far Eastern Front.

In November 1943, 13th Tank Corps was granted the Guards status and became the 4th Guards Mechanized Corps. General Trofim I. Tanaschishin remained its commander. 4th Guards Mechanized Corps was composed of the 13th, 14th and 15th Guards Mechanized Brigades assisted by the 36th Guards Tank Brigade. It served in various Ukrainian Fronts until the end of war.\n\n§RNote for player: 4th Mechanized Corps will be deployed in its 1944 complete version, with all artillery and armored support assets.§W

14th Tank Corps was to be reformed into 6th Mechanized Corps in late 1942, but in early 1943, this formation was granted the Guards status and instead became the 5th Guards Mechanized Corps. General Boris M. Skvortsov was in charge of the 11th, 12th and 13th Guards Mechanized Brigades assisted by the 24th Guards Tank Brigade. It fought within the 5th Guards Tank Army in 1944 and later in the 4th Guards Tank Army.\n\n§RNote for player: 5th Guards Mechanized Corps will be deployed in its 1944 (definitive) version.§W

6th Guards Mechanized Corps was set up in June 1943 in the Moscow Military District, taking the 49th Mechanized Brigade from the 5th Mechanized Corps and building the 16th and 17th Guards Mechanized Brigades using the 3rd Guards Motorized Division. It has no tank brigades but instead the 29th and 56th Tank Regiments. Its commander was General Aleksandr I. Akimov and the corps fought within the 4th Tank Army.

6th Guards Mechanized Corps was upgraded in January 1945 with full artillery assets. Under the command of General Vasilii F. Orlov, it fought within the 4th Guards Tank Army who participated in the last offensives against the Axis.

In August 1943, the 2nd Mechanized Corps of General Ivan P. Korchagin was granted the Guards status and became the 7th Guards Mechanized Corps. It was composed of the 24th, 25th and 26th Mechanized Brigades assisted by the 57th Guards Tank Brigade. This unit stayed in reserve for most of 1944 before being assigned to the 1st Ukrainian Front in 1945 and ended the war in Berlin.\n\n§RNote for player: This corps will be deployed as the 1944 definitive version, with all its artillery and support assets.§W

In August 1943, the 3rd Mechanized Corps of General Semion M. Krivoshein was granted the Guards status and became the 8th Guards Mechanized Corps. It was composed of the 19th, 20th and 21st Mechanized Brigades assisted by the 1st and 64th Guards Tank Brigades. This unit was assigned to the 1st Tank Army, becoming, in May 1944, the 1st Guards Tank Army.\n\n§RNote for player: This corps will be deployed as the 1944 definitive version, with all its artillery and support assets.§W

In September 1944, the 5th Mechanized Corps of General Mikhail V. Volkov was granted the Guards status and became the 9th Guards Mechanized Corps. It was composed of the 18th, 30th and 31st Mechanized Brigades assisted by the 46th Guards Tank Brigade. This last mechanized corps was almost exclusively equipped with Lend Lease M4A2 Shermans. It was assigned to the 6th Guards Tank Army.

From December 1942 to February 1943, Stavka formed 7 Guards Rocket Artillery Divisions, sent to various fronts. Each one was made of 3 rocket artillery brigades, using the famous BM-13 Katyusha rocket launcher, based on a Zis-6 truck.

After successful actions during the Battle of Stalingrad, the 4th Artillery Division was given the Guards status in March 1943, becoming the 2nd Guards Breakthrough Artillery Division.

1st Guards Breakthrough Division was also formed after the Battle of Stalingrad by giving Guards status to the 1st Artillery Division. This division fought in the Battle of Kursk and was later assigned to the 1st Ukrainian Front were it participated in many offensives in Central Europe.

In July 1943, other Guards Artillery Divisions were formed.

The 8th Artillery Division became the 3rd Guards Breakthrough Artillery Division.
The 14th Artillery Division became the 4th Guards Cannon Artillery Division.
The 19th Heavy Artillery Division became the 5th Guards Breakthrough Artillery Division.

§RNote for player: Although these divisions were assigned to the 5th Breakthrough Artillery Corps, they are here formed under an ahistorical Guards Artillery Corps that will receive the surplus artillery brigades.§W
